{{Infobox international basketball competition | tourney_name = | year = | other_titles = | image = 2013 FIBA Americas Championship logo.jpg | size = 130 | alt = | caption = | city = [[Caracas]] | country = Venezuela | dates = August 30 – September 11 | num_teams = 10 | confederations = | federations = 44 | venues = 1 | cities = 1 | champion = Mexico | count = 1 | second = Puerto Rico | third = Argentina | fourth = Dominican Republic | games = | attendance = | mvp = {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Gustavo Ayón]] | top_scorer = {{flagicon|ARG}} [[Luis Scola]]
(18.8 [[points per game]]) | prevseason = [[2011 FIBA Americas Championship|2011]] | nextseason = [[2015 FIBA Americas Championship|2015]] | updated = }} The '''2013 FIBA Americas Championship for Men''', later known as the '''FIBA AmeriCup''', was the qualifying tournament for [[FIBA Americas]], for the [[2014 FIBA Basketball World Cup|2014 FIBA World Cup]], in [[Spain]]. This [[FIBA AmeriCup]] tournament was held in [[Caracas]], [[Venezuela]], from August 30, to September 11, 2013. The top four teams qualified for the 2014 FIBA World Cup. [[Mexico national basketball team|Mexico]] defeated [[Puerto Rico national basketball team|Puerto Rico]], in the final, to win their first AmeriCup title.{{cite web | url=http://caracas2013.com/en/noticiasread4.asp?r=000739EDFBBD47D1B22AC7A4AD004F1E | title=VEN2013 – Mexico is Americas Champion | date=11 September 2013 | accessdate=11 September 2013}} ==Qualification== {{main|2013 FIBA Americas Championship qualification}} *Central American and Caribbean Sub-Zone ([[2012 Centrobasket]]): **{{Bk|DOM}} **{{Bk|PUR}} **{{Bk|JAM}} *North American Sub-Zone: **{{Bk|CAN}} **{{Bk|MEX}}[http://www.caracas2013.com/en/noticiasread4.asp?r=4353AE7A74984087904E5E33E2C7F89B Mexico replaces Panama in Americas Championship] *South American Sub-Zone ([[South American Basketball Championship 2012]]): **{{Bk|ARG}} **{{Bk|VEN}} **{{Bk|URU}} **{{Bk|BRA}} **{{Bk|PAR}} ==Draw== The draw was held at the Catia Theatre in Caracas on February 28. This was how the teams were seeded: {|class=wikitable |- |width=20%| {{bk|ARG}} (3)
{{bk|BRA}} (9) |width=20%| {{bk|PUR}} (19)
{{bk|DOM}} (27) |width=20%| {{bk|MEX}} (32)
{{bk|URU}} (29) |width=20%| {{bk|JAM}} (83)
{{bk|PAR}} (55) |width=20%| {{bk|VEN}} (24)
{{bk|CAN}} (26) |} As hosts, Venezuela picked first the group that they played at, and their final opponent in the preliminary round.{{cite web|url=http://www.fibaamericas.com/en/noticiasread4.asp?r=233B91162E3B489EA704F724CEDFF5C6 |title=VEN2013 – The stage is set for the 2013 FIBA Americas Championship draw |work=[[FIBA Americas]] |date=2013-02-27 |accessdate=2013-09-09}} Included are the last published [[FIBA World Rankings]] prior to the draw. ==Format== The ten teams were split into two groups. The best four teams of each group advanced to the second round, where the teams played against the four teams from the other group; each team carried over all points earned during the first round, except for those earned in the match against the team that was eliminated. The best four teams of this group advanced to the semifinals and were qualified for the [[2014 FIBA Basketball World Cup|2014 FIBA World Cup]]. The United States, which won the Olympic Gold Medal in 2012, automatically qualified for the 2014 FIBA Tournament and does not have to participate as a result. Originally, Panama were supposed to compete for the 2013 FIBA Americas Championship, but was replaced by Mexico after FIBA implemented a suspension on the Panamanian Basketball Federation. Mexico was chosen as the next highest placed finisher in Panama's subcategory (COCABA) at the 2012 Centrobasket tournament. ==Squads== {{Main|2013 FIBA Americas Championship squads}} ==Preliminary round== {|class="infobox bordered" style="font-size:100%" |- |width=10px bgcolor=#ccffcc| ||Qualified for the second round |} ===Group A=== In Group A, team [[Puerto Rico national basketball team|Puerto Rico]] secured their first round undefeated, as well as narrowly clinching their win against surprising newcomer [[Jamaica national basketball team|Jamaica]] 88–82, while [[Canada national basketball team|Canada]] and [[Uruguay national basketball team|Uruguay]] also secured their place for the second round. The Mexican team lost their three-win streak to the Argentine basketball team, while [[Paraguay national basketball team|Paraguay]]'s poor efforts prevented them from winning a single game since their Meanwhile, upstart [[Mexico national basketball team|Mexico]] also clinched their position for the World Cup from their performance, while [[Dominican Republic national basketball team|Dominican Republic]] and [[Argentina national basketball team|Argentina]] also secured their place for the World Cup. Despite the efforts, the Canadian team were unable to put up a defensive and offensive play, thus eliminating the team for the second time since 2011. Newcomers Jamaica was also eliminated, despite winning against the Argentine team, whereas Uruguay were unable to make their debut for the Championship round, losing half of the matches throughout the Second Round. {|class="infobox bordered" style="font-size:100%" |- |width=10px bgcolor=#ccffcc| ||Qualified for the semifinals |} {{Bs cl2 header navbar|tie=yes}} {{Bs cl2 team|t={{Bk|MEX}} |w=5 |l=2 |pf=548 |pa=525 |tie=2–0 |bc=#ccffcc}} {{Bs cl2 team|t={{Bk|DOM}} |w=5 |l=2 |pf=561 |pa=523 |tie=1–1 |bc=#ccffcc}} {{Bs cl2 team|t={{Bk|PUR}} |w=5 |l=2 |pf=587 |pa=548 |tie=0–2 |bc=#ccffcc}} {{Bs cl2 team|t={{Bk|ARG}} |w=4 |l=3 |pf=564 |pa=545 |tie=1–0 |bc=#ccffcc}} {{Bs cl2 team|t={{Bk|VEN}} |w=4 |l=3 |pf=511 |pa=501 |tie=0–1}} {{Bs cl2 team|t={{Bk|CAN}} |w=3 |l=4 |pf=534 |pa=499 |tie= }} {{Bs cl2 team|t={{Bk|URU}} |w=1 |l=6 |pf=482 |pa=584 |tie=1–0}} {{Bs cl2 team|t={{Bk|JAM}} |w=1 |l=6 |pf=527 |pa=589 |tie=0–1}} |} {{basketballbox|bg=#eee|date=5 September 2013|time=11:00|place=[[Poliedro de Caracas]], [[Caracas]] |teamA='''{{Bk-rt|DOM}}''' |scoreA='''78''' |teamB={{Bk|JAM}} |scoreB=60 |Q1='''17'''–11|Q2='''25'''–18|Q3=15–'''16'''|Q4='''21'''–15 |report=[http://www.fiba.com/pages/eng/fe/14/wcm/p/eid/6241/gid/16/grid/X/rid/9796/sid/6584/game.html Boxscore] |points1=[[James Feldeine|Feldeine]] 22 |rebounds1=[[Eulis Báez|Báez]] 10 |assist1=[[Eulis Báez|Báez]] 4 |points2=[[Akeem Scott|A. {{Infobox football club| clubname = Bantu FC| image = Bantu_FC_Logo.png| fullname = Bantu Football Club| nickname = A Mats'o Matebele| founded = 1927| ground = Leshoboro Seeiso Sports Complex [[Mafeteng]], [[Lesotho]]| capacity = 7,000| chairman = Leuta John Leuta| manager = Tseliso Ramatla| coach = James Madidilane| league = [[Lesotho Premier League]]| season = 2016/2017| position = 1st| }}
'''Bantu Football Club''' is a Lesotho football club based in [[Mafeteng]]. It is based in the city of [[Mafeteng]] in the [[Mafeteng District]].
The team currently plays in [[Lesotho Premier League]].<ref>{{Cite web | last = | first = | coauthors = | title =lesotho premier | publisher =soccerway| date =2014 | url =https://int.soccerway.com/teams/lesotho/bantu-fc/17211/matches/ | accessdate =2010-01-15 }}</ref>
==Achievements== *'''[[Lesotho Premier League]]: 3''' ::2014, 2017, 2018.
*'''[[Lesotho Independence Cup|Lesotho Cup]]: 8''' ::1963, 1993, 1997, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2015, 2017.

{{Infobox venue | name = Baynard Stadium | nickname = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | fullname = | former names = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = | address = 1797 Stadium Dr, Wilmington, DE 19802 | location = | coordinates = | type = Stadium | genre = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = {{Start date|1922|June|10}} | renovated = 1956, 1972 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Wilmington, Delaware|City of Wilmington]] | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | production = | cost = | architect = | builder = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = 2,500 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Wilmington Renegades]] ([[Atlantic Coast Football League|ACFL]]) (1966-67)
[[Salesianum School]] ([[Delaware Interscholastic Athletic Association|DIAA]]) (1922–present) | embedded = | website = | publictransit = }} '''Baynard Stadium''' is an athletic stadium located in [[Wilmington, Delaware]]. It opened on June 10, 1922 and was a gift of Samuel H. Baynard, president of the Board of Park Commissioners. In its original configuration the stadium contained two baseball fields and a running track.{{cite news|title=Complete Work On Baynard Stadium|work=The Morning News|date=June 12, 1922}} The stadium, currently owned by the city of Wilmington, was last renovated in 1972. It is used by several local high schools and youth organizations.{{cite news|last1=Myers|first1=Brad|title=Deal for Sallies to fix Banyard back on|work=The News Journal|date=June 28, 2017}} The stadium's seating capacity of 5,000 was cut in half after bleachers on the south side were condemned and eventually demolished.{{cite news|last1=Myers|first1=Brad|title=Banyard Stadium seating capacity cut as south bleachers condemned|work=The News Journal|date=June 2, 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Delaware-sports-venue-stub}} {{coord|39.761061|-75.552867|type:landmark_globe:earth_region:US-DE|display=title}} [[Category:1922 establishments in Delaware]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1922]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Wilmington, Delaware]]

revision.comment: Reverted to revision 854476953 by [[Special:Contributions/76.92.38.67|76.92.38.67]] ([[User talk:76.92.38.67|talk]]): Let's dial it back a little. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox NCAA football single game |Name=Bluegrass Miracle |Date=November 9, 2002 |Year=2002 |Visitor School=Louisiana State |Visitor Name Short=LSU |Visitor Nickname=Tigers |Visitor Record=6–2 |Visitor AP = 16 |Visitor Coaches = 14 |Visitor BCS = |Visitor Coach=[[Nick Saban]] |Visitor1=0 |Visitor2=14 |Visitor3=7 |Visitor4=12 |Visitor Total=33 |Home School=Kentucky |Home Name Short=Kentucky |Home Nickname=Wildcats |Home Record=6–3 |Home AP = NR |Home Coaches = NR |Home BCS = |Home Coach=[[Guy Morriss]] |Home1=7 |Home2=0 |Home3=7 |Home4=16 |Home Total=30 |Type=Non-conference |Stadium=[[Commonwealth Stadium (Kentucky)|Commonwealth Stadium]] |City=[[Lexington, Kentucky]] |Referee= Steve Shaw }}
{| class="infobox bordered" style="width: 25em; text-align: left; font-size: 75%;" |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | [[File:Front-berlin.gif]] The sports page of the [[Baton Rouge]] ''[[The Advocate (Baton Rouge)|Advocate]]'' on November 10, 2002, the day after the "Bluegrass Miracle." The top photo shows [[University of Kentucky|Kentucky]] defenders deflecting the pass, and the large center photo shows [[LSU Tigers football|LSU]] wide receiver Devery Henderson right after catching the pass. |- |}
The '''Bluegrass Miracle''' was a 74-yard game-winning [[touchdown]] pass by the No. 16 [[LSU Tigers football|LSU Tigers]] with no time left on the clock against the [[Kentucky Wildcats football|Kentucky Wildcats]] on November 9, 2002 at [[Commonwealth Stadium (Kentucky)|Commonwealth Stadium]] in [[Lexington, Kentucky]]. The ball was tipped by a Kentucky player before being caught at the 15-yard line by [[Devery Henderson]] of LSU, who ran it in for the score.
==Background== [[University of Kentucky|Kentucky]], the home team, was the underdog to the defending [[Southeastern Conference|SEC]] champion Tigers. LSU was ahead by as many as 14 points at one point and led 24–14 after a field goal with 13:58 left in the fourth quarter, but Kentucky came back with a 13–3 run to tie it at 27. However, a Kentucky player called the Wildcats' last timeout on first down from the LSU 11 with 15 seconds left on the clock, and rather than risking a turnover or a tackle within the field of play that would leave the clock running and the Wildcats unable to line up to spike the football, head coach [[Guy Morriss]] opted to send [[Placekicker|kicker]] Taylor Begley out to kick a 29-yard [[Field goal (football)|field goal]], giving the Wildcats a 30–27 lead with 11 seconds left on the clock. LSU got the ball back, but the ensuing kickoff pinned the team at its own 9-yard line. On the first play of the series, the Tigers quickly got the ball to their own 26-yard line on a pass from [[quarterback]] [[Marcus Randall]] to [[wide receiver]] [[Michael Clayton (American football)|Michael Clayton]]. An LSU timeout stopped the clock with 2 seconds left, and set up a desperation [[Hail Mary pass]]. The chances for success were considered slim because Randall's arm was not strong enough to reach the opponent's [[end zone]] from 70+ yards away. Kentucky players were so confident that they had won the game that they gave Morriss a [[Gatorade shower|Gatorade bath]] before the final play had taken place.<ref>{{cite web| title=Ten years later, Bluegrass Miracle recalled|publisher=theadvocate.com/|url=http://theadvocate.com/sports/lsu/4380648-123/ten-years-later-lsus-improbable|accessdate=2014-05-15}}</ref>
==The play== {{quote box|quote=Randall, as time expires, lets it fly...'''''OH, MY GOODNESS! TOUCHDOWN, LSU! They win the game!''''' They win the football game!|source=[[Dave Neal]]'s call of the play on [[Jefferson Pilot Sports]].|width=31%}} On the final play of the game, LSU called the play "Dash Right 93 Berlin". Tigers quarterback Marcus Randall took the ball and threw it from his own 18 yard line as far as he could downfield. Soon after Randall released the ball, triumphant Kentucky fans stormed the field around Randall. The pass was 25 yards short of the [[end zone]]. However, the ball was deflected off the hand of a Kentucky player between the Kentucky 30 and 25 yard lines and fell into the hands of LSU wide receiver [[Devery Henderson]] just short of the 15-yard line. Henderson broke an attempt at a shoestring tackle by the last Kentucky defender and ran into the end zone for the game-winning touchdown.<ref>{{cite web| title=Remembering LSU's Bluegrass Miracle on the 10th anniversary|publisher= The Times-Picayune|url=http://www.nola.com/lsu/index.ssf/2012/11/remembering_lsus_bluegrass_mir.html|accessdate=2012-05-15}}</ref>
==Confusion and aftermath== While Henderson crossed the end zone, the [[Jefferson Pilot Sports]] television broadcast accidentally posted the graphic "Kentucky 30, LSU 27—FINAL." LSU had actually just won the game 33–30. After the touchdown, Jefferson Pilot Sports [[play-by-play]] announcer [[Dave Neal]] called the play, "The most shocking, improbable, unbelievable sequence of events." In his television interview right after the play, LSU head coach Nick Saban said, "I don't know what to say. I feel bad for Kentucky's players. But this is a big moment for us and I'm happy as heck for our team....Well, sometimes you gotta be a little lucky and I think that was our luck right there." Kentucky fans who were already on the field could not believe what had happened. Fireworks spewed out of the Commonwealth Stadium suites to herald the apparent Kentucky win when the game clock read "0:00", even prior to the Hail Mary pass. After the play, Tom Leach, Kentucky's [[radio]] play-by-play announcer, said, "How much heartbreak. (Kentucky) fans are up on the [[goal post]]s. I don't know why." LSU's play-by-play announcer [[Jim Hawthorne (sportscaster)|Jim Hawthorne]], was equally shocked and was also at a loss for an explanation; he initially said that LSU [[defensive back]] [[Jack Hunt (American football)|Jack Hunt]] (who had converted from wide receiver in 2002), not Devery Henderson, scored the touchdown. Hunt's uniform number was 8; Henderson's was 9.<ref>{{cite web| title=Best College Football Buzzer Beaters - Bluegrass Miracle|publisher=sports.yahoo.com/|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/ncaaf-dr-saturday/doc-five-best-college-football-buzzer-beaters-no-175030153--ncaaf.html|accessdate=2014-05-15}}</ref>
==Naming the play== On the day after the game, [[Baton Rouge]]'s daily newspaper, ''[[The Advocate (Baton Rouge)|The Advocate]]'', ran the headline "HAIL TIGERS" on the sports page. The headline is a reference to the [[Hail Mary pass]] used to win the game. On back of the sports page, it also provided a shot-by-shot camera sequence of the play. The page also included a graphic outlining the sequence of events. They were accompanied by the headline "Dash Right 93 Berlin," which was the play run that won the game.
The play became permanently known as the "Bluegrass Miracle" after a poll of LSU fans was conducted on the LSU Sports website days later. Other website suggestions for the name included "The Bluegrass Bomb" and "Miracle on the Bluegrass." The website also received write-in votes for such names as "The Divine Deflection," "It Works Devery Time," and "The Lexington Longshot."<ref>{{cite web| title=Over 10,000 vote to name legendary LSU play|publisher=espn.com|url=http://a.espncdn.com/ncf/news/2002/1114/1460861.html|accessdate=2014-05-15}}</ref>
==Awards and records== The "Bluegrass Miracle" also won the 2003 [[Best Play ESPY Award]]. It beat out plays from [[Kobe Bryant]], [[LeBron James]], [[Michael Vick]] and [[Barry Bonds]]. [[Devery Henderson]] accepted the award on behalf of the LSU team. It was the second time an LSU miracle play won an [[ESPY]] award: [[Warren Morris]] had won the 1997 [[Showstopper of the Year ESPY Award]] for his two out, walk-off [[home run]] in the [[1996 College World Series]] championship game.
It also marked the second time in as many years that LSU foiled a Kentucky football [[comeback (sports)|comeback]] in the final moments of the game. In the 2001 game, also at Kentucky, the Tigers won 29–25, on a touchdown pass from [[Marcus Randall]] to [[Devery Henderson]] with 13 seconds left in the game. Earlier in the game, Kentucky had overcome a 12-point halftime deficit to take the lead in the 4th quarter.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VIJOq9SOeek LSU's Bluegrass Miracle 10 Years Later] YouTube video
{{LSU Tigers football navbox}}

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Dartford (borough) to [[:Category:Borough of Dartford]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
'''Bowman's Lodge''' is a house in [[Dartford]], [[Kent]] and the location of Bowmans, an area in the north west of [[Dartford Heath]]. The historian John Dunkin wrote{{Cite book|title=The History and Antiquities of Dartford|last=Dunkin|first=John|publisher=J. & W. Davis|year=1844|isbn=|location=|pages=358-361}} that Bowman's Lodge was so named "from having been taken by the Royal Society of Kentish Bowmen...where their first meetings were held. At the formation eleven gentlemen only enrolled their names but in 1786 their numbers increased to 30 and in the following year when their meetings were removed to Dartford Heath and held every Saturday during the months of May, June, July and August they numbered 61 and when it was known to be patronized by [[George_IV_of_the_United_Kingdom|His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales]] the numbers increased to 123, among whom were some of the highest nobility. The Heath again became the favourite resort of youth and beauty, assembled to behold the splendid costume of the members, and witness their skill in archery". He continued: "The house is traditionally said to have been the scene of many midnight revels and orgies. The members previous to the breaking up of the society, fitted up an apartment, in which they frequently acted plays and other dramatic pieces, to which the inhabitants of the neighbourhood were invited by tickets".
Here knights and damsels met in splendid show Hailed the bright goddess of the silver bow, And maids of Kent, expert in piercing hearts, Supplied the archers with their eyes for darts; From Love's artillery discharged their lances And vanquish [[Kent|Cantia]]'s heroes with their glances. — Ye Virgin Sisters of chaste [[Diana (mythology)|Dian]]'s train Have pity on the Archers ye have slain For oh, what armour can secure be found When arrows sharp as yours inflict the wound.
''A poem presented to E.M. Potts at Bowman's Lodge c. 1834; lines by Miss Talbot, published in "Moonshine", p.346'' {{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=GjpVnsa93CYC&source=gbs_book_other_versions|title=Moonshine [by E.M. Potts]. [With] To my grandchildren [and] Extracts|last=Potts|first=Ethelinda Margaretta|date=1835|language=en}}
In 1779-80 a shop, the Suttling house, stood near Bowman's Lodge, kept by Mr. Powell of the Granby, Dartford, for the purpose of supplying troops with stationery and small stores while they were camped on the heath preparing for a foreign invasion.{{Infobox cricket ground | ground = Bowman's Lodge | image = | caption =Kent county cricket location | location = [[Dartford]], [[Kent]] | home club = | county club = [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent]] | established = 1795 | last used = 1809 }} Bowman's Lodge was the venue for four [[cricket]] matches played between 1795 and 1809 which were given retrospective [[first-class cricket]] status. Two matches were held between [[All-England cricket teams|an England side]] and [[Hampshire county cricket teams|a Hampshire team]] in 1795. A [[Kent county cricket teams|Kent side]] played England in 1805 and the final top-class match at the ground came in 1809 between England and [[Surrey county cricket teams|a Surrey team]].[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/448_f.html First-Class Matches played on Bowman's Lodge], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2017-12-17. The exact location of the ground on the heath is unknown, though the land opposite the lodge is presently laid out with [[Association football|football]] pitches and is a possible site of the cricket matches. For about 60 years, the lodge was home to William Cracroft Fooks QC (1812-99), [[Barrister at Law]], JP for the county of Kent.{{Cite web|url=http://dartfordhistory.blogspot.co.uk/2017/05/william-cracroft-fooks-qc-1812-99.html|title=William Cracroft Fooks QC (1812-99), Barrister at Law|website=dartfordhistory.blogspot.co.uk|access-date=2017-12-21}} He was instrumental in the rejection of a proposal to build a ship canal from the Thames to [[Dartford Creek]]. He also organised the formation of a volunteer rifle corps in the Dartford area to prepare for a possible invasion of Britain by [[Napoleon III]]. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries gravel was excavated in the area and numerous [[Palaeolithic]] [[stone tool|flint implements]] were discovered in Bowman's Lodge Pit, which was located between the house and Chastilian Road{{cite book|last1=Tester|first1=P.J.|title=Archaeologia Cantiana Vol. 63|date=1950|publisher=Kent Archaeological Society|pages=122|url=http://www.kentarchaeology.org.uk/Research/Pub/ArchCant/Vol.063%20-%201950/063-07.pdf}}. In the 20th century the pit was [[Landfill|filled in]] and returned to [[Heath|heathland]]. The lodge is thought to have had connections with Lord Tredegar until well into the 1900s. It was torn down in about 1987 and replaced with two modern dwellings. Swan Lane, the road running past the property, remained a dirt track until the 1980s when it was upgraded and became part of the main signposted route to [[Crayford]] from the Dartford Heath junction of the [[A2 road (Great Britain)|A2]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{English cricket venues to 1825}} [[Category:1795 establishments in England]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in Kent]] [[Category:Cricket in Kent]] [[Category:Borough of Dartford]] [[Category:Defunct cricket grounds in England]] [[Category:Defunct sports venues in Kent]] [[Category:English cricket venues in the 18th century]] [[Category:History of Kent]] [[Category:Kent]] [[Category:Sport in Kent]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1795]] [[Category:Sports venues in Kent]] {{Kent-struct-stub}} {{England-cricket-ground-stub}}

[[SC Magdeburg]] is the only handball club who has won the European club title while representing two different countries (e.g. [[East Germany]] and [[Germany]]).'' ====Notes==== *{{note label|SU|A|A}}Results until the [[Dissolution of the Soviet Union]] in 1991. Three out of five titles were won by clubs from present day [[Belarus]], while two titles and the additional three times runners-up were achieved by clubs from present day [[Russia]]. *{{note label|YUG|B|B}}Results until the [[Breakup of Yugoslavia]] in early 1990s. Clubs from present day [[Serbia]] won the title two times and were runners-up additional two times, clubs from present day [[Croatia]] won the title once and were runners-up three times, clubs from present day [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] won the title once and were runners-up once, while clubs from present day [[Slovenia]] were runners-up one time. *{{note label|CZE|C|C}}Results until the [[Dissolution of Czechoslovakia]] in 1993. {{unreferenced|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = F.C. Djaraf| image = | fullname = F.C. Djaraf| nickname = | founded = | ground = Orfaso Namalota da Canchungo
[[Canchungo]], [[Guinea-Bissau]]| capacity = 5,000| chairman = | league = Campeonato Assotiation da Guiné-Bissau | season = 2007/08 | position = | pattern_la1=_whiteshoulders|pattern_b1=_whiteshoulders|pattern_ra1=_whiteshoulders| leftarm1=000000|body1=FFFFFF|rightarm1=000000|shorts1=000000|socks1=000000| pattern_la2=|pattern_b2=_unknown|pattern_ra2=| leftarm2=FFFFFF|body2=FFFFFF|rightarm2=FFFFFF|shorts2=FFFFFF|socks2=FFFFFF| }} '''Futebol Clube Djaraf''' is a [[Bissau-Guinean]] [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Canchungo]], a city located in the [[Cacheu Region]] in the northwest. They play in the 2 division in Guinean football, the [[Campeonato Nacional da Guiné-Bissau]]. The club is named after the rulers during pre-colonial times, in Serer and in Canchungo ([[Wolof language|Wolof]] ''Jaraaf'', [[Mandjak language|Mandjak]]: approximately as ''Jarāf''). ==See also== *[[ASC Diaraf]], also known as Djaraf, sometimes as Jaraaf, a Senegalese club based in Dakar also named after the rulers of pre-colonial times [[Category:Football clubs in Guinea-Bissau|Djaraf]] [[Category:Cacheu Region|Djaraf]] {{GuineaBissau-footyclub-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:The Childrens Museum of Indianapolis - Sled.jpg|thumbnail|right|A Flexible Flyer sled, from 1936, within the permanent collection of [[The Children's Museum of Indianapolis]].]]
'''Flexible Flyer''' is a toy and recreational equipment brand, best known for the sled of the same name, a steerable wooden [[sled]] with steel runners.
== Operation ==
Flexible Fliers are flexible both in design and usage. Riders may sit upright on the sled or lie on their stomachs, allowing the possibility to descend a snowy slope feet-first or head-first. To steer the sled, riders may either push on the wooden cross piece with their hands or feet, or pull on the rope attached to the wooden cross-piece. Shifting the cross-piece one way or the other causes the flexible rails to bend, turning the sled.<ref>[http://www.philly.com/philly/blogs/TODAY-IN-PHILADELPHIA-HISTORY/Samuel-Leeds-Allen-patents-the-Flexible-Flyer.html Samuel Leeds Allen patents the Flexible Flyer - Today in Philadelphia History]</ref>
Flexible Flyers work best on hard packed or icy snow. If the snow is soft and deep, the sled's runners are likely to sink in and prevent the sled from moving.
== History ==
[[File:Flexible Flyer Ad.jpg|thumb|left|Flexible Flyer ad from the early 1900s]]
[[Samuel Leeds Allen]] [[patented]] the Flexible Flyer in 1889.<ref>http://www.westtown.edu/about-westtown/history/more-history/sledding-at-westtown/index.aspx</ref> in [[Cinnaminson, New Jersey]] using local children and adults to test prototypes.<ref>{{cite news | last = Hatala | first = Greg | title = Made in Jersey: Flexible Flyer - The sled from south Jersey | publisher = The Star-Ledger | date = January 7, 2014 | url = http://www.nj.com/business/index.ssf/2014/01/made_in_jersey_flexible_flyer_-_the_sled_from_south_jersey.html#incart_river#incart_hbx#incart_best-of | accessdate = 2013-12-22}}</ref> Allen's company flourished by selling these speedy and yet controllable sleds at a time when others were still producing [[toboggans]] and "gooseneck" sleds.<ref>{{cite book|editor-last=Pellegrini|editor-first=Anthony D.|title=The future of play theory: a multidisciplinary inquiry into the contributions of Brian Sutton-Smith|year=1995|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=978-0-7914-2641-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8_NBW3q__PgC&dq=flexible+flyer+history&lr=&source=gbs_navlinks_s|author=Bernard Mergen|chapter=Past play: relics, memory, and history|page=260}}</ref>
Allen began producing sleds in his [[farm equipment]] factory to keep his workers busy even when it was not the farm season. He developed many prototypes before he created the Flexible Flyer. The sleds did not sell well until he began marketing them to the toy departments of [[department stores]]. In 1915, around 120,000 Flexible Fliers were sold, and almost 2,000 Flexible Flyers were sold in one day.
In 1968, Leisure Group of Los Angeles, California bought the S. L. Allen Company. Leisure Group continued to produce Flexible Flyers in [[Medina, Ohio]]. In 1973, a group of [[private investors]] bought Leisure Group's toy division and started manufacturing the sleds under the name "Blazon Flexible Flyer" in [[West Point, Mississippi]]. In 1993, Roadmaster purchased the rights to production and moved production to [[Olney, Illinois]], and in 1998, production was moved to China. {{As of|2012}}, Flexible Flyers are mostly made in China and some are made in [[South Paris, Maine]]<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.boston.com/sports/outdoors/articles/2011/12/25/flexible_flyer_king_of_sleds_slides_on/ | work=The Boston Globe | title=Flexible Flyer, king of sleds, slides on | date=25 December 2011}}</ref> by Paricon, Inc.<ref>http://pariconsleds.com/index.php/classic-sleds.html</ref>
== Examples == <gallery> File:Flexible Flyer on Tree.jpg|Flexible Flyer leaning against a tree File:Flexible Flyers in Snow.jpg|Flexible Flyers in the snow File:Boy on snow sled, 1945.jpg|Boy on a Flexible Flyer, 1945 </gallery>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[https://www.pariconsleds.com/about/ About Paricon Sleds] *[http://www.google.com/patents?vid=408681 U.S. Patent 408,681] *[http://explorepahistory.com/hmarker.php?markerId=1099 Biographical information about Samuel L. Allen] *[http://www.uspto.gov/web/offices/ac/ahrpa/opa/kids/themes/flexflyr.htm The Story of the Flexible Flyer]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Flexible Flyer}} [[Category:American inventions]] [[Category:Sledding]] [[Category:Sports equipment]] [[Category:Sliding vehicles]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{coord|53.6480|-1.7833|type:landmark_region:GB_scale:5000|display=title}} [[File:George Hotel (4931213893).jpg|thumb|right|250px|George Hotel, Huddersfield]] The '''George Hotel''' in [[Huddersfield]], [[West Yorkshire]], England, is a [[Grade II#England and Wales|Grade II]] listed building famous as the birthplace of [[rugby league football]] in 1895.<ref name="George">{{cite web |url=http://www.thegeorgehotelhuddersfield.co.uk/ |title=The George Hotel |publisher=The George Hotel |accessdate=7 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080725020636/http://www.thegeorgehotelhuddersfield.co.uk/ |archivedate=25 July 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The 60 bed hotel was built in 1851 and closed in January 2013, with the [[receivership|receivers]] looking for a new buyer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-leeds-20900561|title=Huddersfield's historic George Hotel closes|date=3 January 2013|publisher=|accessdate=3 January 2013|work=BBC News}}</ref>
The three-star rated George Hotel, which has an [[Italianate architecture|Italianate façade]], was designed by William Walker.<ref name="Direct">{{cite web|url=http://www.direct-hotels.co.uk/hotel-George-Hotel-Huddersfield-code05909-UI.htm |title=Property Information: George Hotel, Huddersfield |publisher=Direct Hotels |accessdate=7 July 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080406114642/http://www.direct-hotels.co.uk/hotel-George-Hotel-Huddersfield-code05909-UI.htm |archivedate=6 April 2008 |deadurl=yes }}</ref><ref name="Expedia">{{cite web |url=http://www.expedia.co.uk/pub/agent.dll/qscr=dspv/nojs=1/htid=16691 |title=George Hotel |publisher=Expedia |accessdate=7 July 2008}}</ref><ref name="BBCa">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/bradford/360/version2_george_hotel.shtml |title=West Yorkshire in 360°! - Founders' Room, Huddersfield |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=7 July 2008}}</ref> The Victorian era hotel was built around 1851.<ref name= "Expedia"/>
==Birth of Rugby League== {{See|History of rugby league}}
It was in the George Hotel, Huddersfield on 29 August 1895 that 21 Lancashire and Yorkshire clubs held a meeting and by a majority of 20 to 1 voted to [[History of rugby league|secede]] from the [[Rugby Football Union]] to set up their own [[Rugby Football League|Northern Rugby Football Union]]. In 1922 this became the [[Rugby Football League]].
Stockport was also accepted into the league via telephone to the hotel.<ref name="BBCb">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/bradford/content/panoramas/new_founders_room_1_360.shtml |title=Rugby League Founders' Room |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=7 July 2008}}</ref>
Memorabilia recalling the meeting can be found throughout the hotel as well as in the Heritage Centre.<ref name="Expedia"/>
==British Amateur Rugby League Association==
The [[British Amateur Rugby League Association]] (BARLA) was also founded at the George Hotel in 1973.
==Rugby League Heritage Centre== {{Main|Rugby League Heritage Centre}}
The Rugby League Heritage Centre was located in the basement of the George. It was the UK’s only rugby league heritage museum. It was the brainchild of sports presenter [[Mike Stephenson]].
The Rugby League Heritage centre was opened on 30 August 2005 by former players [[Billy Boston]], [[Neil Fox (rugby league)|Neil Fox]] and [[Mick Sullivan]].<ref name="rlheritage">{{cite web |url=http://www.rlheritage.co.uk/ |title=Gillette Rugby League Heritage Centre |publisher=Rugby League Heritage Centre |accessdate=7 July 2008}}</ref>
Within the centre were displays of memorabilia, including rare jerseys, medals, caps, programmes and photographs. There was also footage played on several plasma screens. The [[British Rugby League Hall of Fame]] is now located in the Heritage Centre.
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{commonscat}} * [http://www.brook-hotels.co.uk/hotels/yorkshire/huddersfield/george-hotel/ Official George Hotel site] * [http://www.rlheritage.co.uk/ Official Rugby League Heritage Centre site] * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/bradford/360/version2_george_hotel.shtml 360° view of the Founders' Room, George Hotel, Huddersfield] [[Category:Rugby league in England]] [[Category:Rugby league museums and halls of fame]] [[Category:Sport in Huddersfield]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Huddersfield]] [[Category:Grade II listed buildings in West Yorkshire]] [[Category:Grade II listed hotels]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Huddersfield]] [[Category:Sports museums in England]] [[Category:History of rugby league]] [[Category:Hotels in West Yorkshire]] [[Category:Rugby football culture]] [[Category:Defunct museums in England]] [[Category:2005 establishments in England]] [[Category:Museums established in 2005]]

{{Football club infobox | clubname = JS Vieux-Habitants | image = JS Vieux-Habitants.png | image_size = 200px | fullname = Jeunesse Sportive Vieux-Habitants | nickname = | founded = | ground = [[Stade Municipal de Vieux-Habitants]],
[[Vieux-Habitants]], [[Guadeloupe]] | capacity = | chairman = {{flagicon|Guadeloupe|local}} [[Gérard Suzanne]] | manager = {{flagicon|Guadeloupe|local}} [[Dominique Mocka]]
{{flagicon|Guadeloupe|local}} [[Daniel Cangou ]]
{{flagicon|Guadeloupe|local}} [[Daniel Linon]] | league = [[Guadeloupe Championnat National]] | season = 2009/10 | position = 1st | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=FF0000|body1=FF0000|rightarm1=FF0000|shorts1=008000|socks1=FF0000 }} '''JS Vieux-Habitants''' is a [[football (soccer)|football]], or as American's know [[Association football]]/ soccer, club of [[Guadeloupe]], based in the town of [[Vieux-Habitants]]. This is a national known team and many people participate in the event. Some people across the nation even participate in a betting or gambling feature known as [[Fantasy football (association)]]. Here, they can make wagers on which team they think will win and compete other people with their "team". Whoever scores the most points wins the fantasy round. They play in Guadeloupe's first division, the [[Guadeloupe Championnat National]]. After, they post the results so you can keep up on which team won or lost. ==Achievements== *'''[[Guadeloupe Championnat National]]: 2''' :: 2006, 2010 ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090109162345/http://foot2gwada.blogs.francefootball.com/effectifs_des_clubs_de_dh/ Tour des clubs 2008–2009] – Gwadafoot {{fr|icon}} * [http://www.fff.fr/competitions/php/club/club_fiche.php?cl_no=4071 Club info] – French Football Federation {{fr|icon}} * https://int.soccerway.com/teams/guadeloupe/js-vieux-habitants/13319/ {{Guadeloupe Division d’Honneur}} [[Category:Football clubs in Guadeloupe|Vieux-Habitants]] {{Guadeloupe-footyclub-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} This '''list of 10 metre air pistol records''' documents the best performances in [[10 metre air pistol]] recognized as records by various official instances since 1 January 1989, when targets were changed and all records reset, and also the progression of the World and Olympic records.
== Men's qualification round == The men's qualification round consists of 60 shots, and the maximum possible score is 600.
{| |style="vertical-align: top"|
=== World record progression === Since introduction in 1969:<ref name="AUT" /> {|class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%" !Score !Shooter !Date !Comp !Place |- |rowspan=2 style="vertical-align: top"|385 |{{flagathlete|H. Mertel|FRG}} |1969 |ECH |[[Plzeň|Pilsen]], [[Czechoslovakia]] |- |{{flagathlete|Rasskazov|URS|1955}} |1969 |ECH |[[Plzeň|Pilsen]], [[Czechoslovakia]] |- |387 |{{flagathlete|V. == Men's final == The final consists of an additional 10 shots, for a total maximum of 109.0 points. Records are ratified for the aggregate (qualification + final) score of maximum 709.0 points.

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=June 2012}} '''The Marylebone Cricket Club Grounds''' (''MCC Grounds'' for short) is a [[Belize]]an football stadium, located on the Northside of [[Belize City]], Belize.
== Football == It has traditionally been the homefield of all Belize City clubs that participate in national and international competitions. It is currently being occupied by [[FC Belize]] of the [[Premier League of Belize]] (PLB).
It also plays host to primary school and high school football competitions.
== History == The Grounds opened in the 1950s on the site known as the Barracks and was named after an English cricket team (Belize was a British colony). The MCC has since played host to numerous matches between City teams and visitors in the [[Belize Premier Football League]], now the [[Premier League of Belize]], and competitions sponsored by [[UNCAF]] and [[CONCACAF]].
{{coord|17|30|16|N|88|11|21|W|region:BZ_type:landmark_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=title}}
[[Category:Belize Premier Football League home stadiums]] [[Category:Football venues in Belize]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Belize City]] [[Category:1950s establishments in British Honduras]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in the 20th century]]

{{Infobox stadium |stadium_name=Mackay Stadium |nickname= |image=Mackay 10oct2015.jpg |image_size=275px |address=1664 North Virginia Street |location=[[Reno, Nevada]], United States |coordinates={{Coord|39|32|49|N|119|49|3|W|type:landmark|display=it}} |broke_ground={{Start date and age|1964|6|11}}{{cite news |title=Groundbreaking Ceremony Held For New Stadium|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/78986084/|newspaper=|date=June 12, 1964|accessdate=September 8, 2018|page=10}} |opened={{Start date and age|1966|10|1}} |expanded=1978, 1990–1992 and 2006 |closed= |demolished= |owner=[[University of Nevada, Reno]] |operator=University of Nevada, Reno |surface=Natural grass (1966–1999)
[[FieldTurf]] (2000–present) |construction_cost=$11.5 million (2016 renovation), $6.5 million (previous expansions) |architect=Worth Group Architects (previous expansions) |former_names= |record_attendance=33,391
(vs. [[UNLV Rebels football|UNLV]], 1995) |seating_capacity=7,500 (1966–1977)
14,000 (1978–1990)
26,000 (1991)
31,545 (1992–2005)
29,993 (2006–2012)
30,000 (2013–2015)
26,000 (2016)
27,000 (2017–present) |tenants=[[Nevada Wolf Pack football|Nevada Wolf Pack]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1966–present) }} '''Mackay Stadium''' is an outdoor athletic [[stadium]] in [[Reno, Nevada]] on the campus of the [[University of Nevada, Reno]]. It is the university's venue for [[College football|football]] and [[College soccer|women's soccer]] for the [[Nevada Wolf Pack]] of the [[Mountain West Conference]]. It was named after the Mackay family, benefactors of the university by [[Clarence Mackay|Clarence]] and [[John William Mackay|John Mackay]]. ==History== Located on the northern portion of campus, at 17th Street & East Stadium Way, the stadium opened {{Years or months ago|1966|10}} on October 1, [[1966 college football season|1966]] with a [[seating capacity]] of 7,500. It replaced the original Mackay Stadium, formerly located in the bowl containing Hilliard Plaza, the Mack Social Sciences building, and the Reynolds School of Journalism. Both stadiums were named for the Mackay family, who were university benefactors in the early years of the school. The stadium currently seats 27,000 and has played to crowds in excess.{{cite web |title=Mackay Stadium: Around Campus|url=http://www.unr.edu/around-campus/facilities/mackay-stadium|publisher=University of Nevada, Reno|accessdate=October 5, 2014}}{{cite web |title=Facilities: Mackay Stadium|url=http://www.nevadawolfpack.com/facilities/mackay-stadium.html|publisher=University of Nevada, Reno Department of Athletics|accessdate=October 5, 2014}}{{cite web |title=Nevada Football 2014 Media Guide|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/unv/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/2014-15/misc_non_event/2014FBMediaGuide.pdf|publisher=University of Nevada, Reno Department of Athletics|year=2014|accessdate=September 28, 2014}} The field sits at an [[elevation]] of {{convert|4610|ft|m}} [[Metres above sea level|above sea level]]{{cite web |title=USGS: Reno, NV, -119.81870, 39.54987|url=http://msrmaps.com/image.aspx?T=2&S=11&Z=11&X=644&Y=10953&W=3&qs=%7cReno%7cNV|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029201743/http://msrmaps.com/image.aspx?T=2&S=11&Z=11&X=644&Y=10953&W=3&qs=%7cReno%7cNV|dead-url=no|archive-date=October 29, 2013|date=July 1, 1982|work=[[United States Geological Survey]]|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|accessdate=October 6, 2011}} and runs in a NW to SE configuration, with the [[press box]] on the southwest sideline. ===Renovations=== Permanent lighting was installed in 2003 to allow the option of night games. Originally natural grass, synthetic infill [[FieldTurf]] was installed in 2000 and replaced in [[2010 Nevada Wolf Pack football team|2010]].{{cite web |title=Watch the Mackay Stadium FieldTurf Installation|url=http://www.nevadawolfpack.com/genrel/071210aaa.html|publisher=University of Nevada, Reno Department of Athletics|accessdate=July 12, 2010}} In 2013, the playing surface at Mackay Stadium was named [[Chris Ault]] Field in honor of the former Wolf Pack head coach, College Football Hall of Famer, creator of the Pistol offense in 2005 and for his contributions to Wolf Pack football.{{cite web |title='Chris Ault Field' unveiled on Saturday|url=http://www.unr.edu/nevada-today/news/2013/chris-ault-field-dedicated|publisher=University of Nevada, Reno|date=September 9, 2013|accessdate=November 30, 2013}}{{cite news |title=Chris Ault Deserves Warm Send-Off on Night Mackay Stadium's Field is Named After Him|first=Chris|last=Murray|url=http://blogs.rgj.com/chrismurray/2013/09/04/legend-chris-ault-deserves-warm-send-off-on-night-mackay-stadium-field-is-named-after-him/|newspaper=[[Reno Gazette-Journal]]|date=September 4, 2013|accessdate=November 30, 2013}} A proposal passed by the Nevada Board of Regents ([[Nevada System of Higher Education|NSHE]]) upgraded seating options to the stadium for the 2016 season. This renovation has improved the quality of the fans' experiences but decreased the overall stadium capacity to 26,000. Higher ticket fees in the upgraded sections will repay this $11.5 million bond by 2031.{{cite news |title=Regents Approve $11.5 Million Mackay Stadium Renovation|first=Chris|last=Murray|url=http://www.rgj.com/story/sports/college/nevada/2014/12/05/regents-approve-million-mackay-stadium-renovation/19965149/|newspaper=[[Reno Gazette-Journal]]|date=December 5, 2014|accessdate=December 6, 2014}}{{cite news |title=Wolf Pack Proposes 'Game-Changing' $11.5 Million Renovation of Mackay Stadium|first=Chris|last=Murray|url=http://www.rgj.com/story/sports/college/nevada/2014/11/21/wolf-pack-proposes-game-changing-million-renovation-mackay-stadium/19341155/|newspaper=[[Reno Gazette-Journal]]|date=November 24, 2014|accessdate=November 24, 2014}} ==Attendance== The [[Nevada Wolf Pack football|Wolf Pack football]] single-season attendance record was set in 1991 with a total of 180,457 fans over nine home games, including playoffs; and the regular-season attendance record was set at 151,081 fans in 1993. The single-season attendance record for a Wolf Pack team with a losing record (at 149,635 fans) was set in 2013. 2014 was the third football season to have at least 20,000 fans in attendance at every home game (1993 and 2013), although multiple seasons were close. ===Top 25 single-game attendance records=== {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !style="{{CollegePrimaryStyle|Nevada Wolf |- |10.||1986||136,021||10 games (7 season, 3 playoff)||13–1 |} ==Other uses== The [[University of Nevada, Reno|Nevada]] women's soccer team has hosted home crowds with over 1,000 on three occasions. The record was actually set at the Moana Sports Complex in Reno on September 15, 2013, with a record of 1,050 fans in attendance, where the Wolf Pack beat the [[Sacramento State Hornets]], 3–2.{{cite web |title=Nevada Defeats Sacramento State, 3-2|url=http://www.nevadawolfpack.com/sports/w-soccer/recaps/091613aad.html|publisher=University of Nevada, Reno Department of Athletics|date=September 16, 2013|accessdate=November 30, 2013}}{{cite web |title=Sacramento State vs Nevada (Sep 15, 2013)|url=http://www.nevadawolfpack.com/sports/w-soccer/stats/2013-2014/nevgm7.html|publisher=University of Nevada, Reno Department of Athletics|date=September 15, 2013|accessdate=November 30, 2013}} Soccer's home-game attendance record at Mackay Stadium is 1,043 fans, as the Wolf Pack beat [[Wyoming Cowboys and Cowgirls|Wyoming]], 1–0, on October 18, 2015.{{cite web |title=Wyoming vs Nevada (Oct 18, 2015)|url=http://www.nevadawolfpack.com/sports/w-soccer/stats/2015-2016/wy-nv.html|publisher=University of Nevada, Reno Department of Athletics|date=October 18, 2015|accessdate=October 9, 2016}} The third-largest Nevada soccer game with over 1,000 fans was also held at Mackay Stadium with 1,007 fans on September 23, 2012, as the Wolf Pack lost 0-3 to [[California Golden Bears|#15 California]].{{cite web |title=No. 15 California Defeats Nevada|url=http://www.nevadawolfpack.com/sports/w1-soccer/recaps/092312aaa0.html|publisher=University of Nevada, Reno Department of Athletics|date=September 23, 2012|accessdate=November 30, 2013}}{{Dead link|date=November 2016}}{{cite web |title=CAL vs Nevada (Sep 23, 2012)|url=http://www.nevadawolfpack.com/sports/w-soccer/stats/2012-2013/201210.html|publisher=University of Nevada, Reno Department of Athletics|date=September 23, 2012|accessdate=October 9, 2016}} Pack Football and Wolf Pack Soccer] * [https://www.unr.edu/around-campus/mackay-stadium Mackay Stadium – University of Nevada, Reno] {{Nevada Wolf Pack football navbox}} {{University of Nevada}} revision.comment: fix % bug in <math> use \% to avoid parse errors
revision.text:
In [[baseball statistics]], '''NERD''' (a wink towards the [[mnemonic]] "Narration, Exposition, Reflection, Description") is a quantitative measure of expected aesthetic value. NERD was originally created by [[Carson Cistulli]]<ref name="introducing">{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/introducing-nerd/|title=Introducing NERD|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=Fangraphs.com}}</ref> and is part of his project of exploring the "art" of [[sabermetrics|sabermetric research]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/the-long-hello-some-notes-on-luck/|title=The Long Hello: Some Notes on Luck|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=Fangraphs.com}}</ref> The original NERD formula only took into account the [[pitcher]]'s expected performance<ref name="introducing" /> while the current model factors in the entire team's performance.<ref name="team">{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/introducing-team-nerd/|title=Introducing Team NERD|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=Fangraphs.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.thescore.com/djf/2012/08/17/alright-its-the-getting-blanked-podcast-episode-64/|title=Getting Blanked Podcast Episode 64|accessdate=2012-11-15|publisher=thescore.com}}</ref>
==History== The premise for NERD was developed in Cistulli's piece "Why We Watch" in which he establishes the five reasons that baseball continues to captivate the American imagination from game to game: "Pitching Matchups," "Statistically Notable (or Otherwise Compelling) Players," "Rookies (and Debuts)," "Seasonal Context," and "Quality of Broadcast".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/why-we-watch/|title=Why We Watch|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=Fangraphs.com}}</ref> Fellow sabermatrician [[Rob Neyer]], who had collaborated with Cistulli on this piece,<ref name=throneberries>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/sweetspot/post/_/id/3751/thursday-throneberries-9|title=Thursday Throneberries|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=Espn.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://metsminorsreview.libsyn.com/mets-minors-review-volume-16|title=Mets Minors Review Episode 16|accessdate=2012-11-15|publisher=Mets Minors Review}}</ref> wrote "the only thing missing [...] is a points system that would let us put a number on each game"<ref name=throneberries /> and on June 2, 2010 Cistulli unveiled the NERD Pitching formula.<ref name="introducing" />
==NERD pitching== NERD pitching tries to determine which pitchers will be the most aesthetically appealing to watch for a baseball fan and is both a historical and a predictive statistic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/one-night-only-now-with-more-nerd/|title=One Night Only Now with More NERD|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=Fangraphs.com}}</ref> The NERD pitching formula uses a player's standard deviations from the mean (a weighted z-score<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ussmariner.com/2010/06/23/a-post-in-five-parts/|title=A post in Five Parts|accessdate=2011-02-16|publisher=USS Mariner}}</ref>) of the [[Defense independent pitching statistics|DIPS]] statistic xFIP (expected Fielding Independent Pitching), swinging strike percentage, overall strike percentage, and the differential between the pitcher's [[Earned run average|ERA]] and xFIP to determine a quantitative value for each pitcher.<ref name="introducing" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/strasburg-breaks-nerd/|title=Strasburg Breaks NERD|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=Fangraphs.com}}</ref>
<math>p\text{NERD} = (x \text{FIP}z \times 2) + (\text{SwStrk}\%z/2) + (\text{Strike}\%z / 2) + \text{LUCK} + 4.69</math>
The factor of 4.69 is added to make the number fit on a 0 to 10 scale. While there has been some disagreement on the calculation of Cistulli's luck component,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hardballtimes.com/main/blog_article/why-you-cant-subtract-fip-from-era/|title=Why You Can't Subtract FIP from ERA|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=The Hardball Times}}</ref> the general consensus among sports writers seems to be that a player with a below-average ERA and an above-average xFIP has been "unlucky".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ghostrunneronfirst.com/2010/06/getting-nerdy-with-jays-starters.html|title=Getting nerdy|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=Ghost Runner on First}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://itsaboutthemoney.net/archives/2010/09/12/joba-and-fip/|title=Joba and FIP|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=It's About the Money}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=simmons/100402|title=Finally on board the sabermetrics revolution|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=Espn.com}}</ref>
==Team NERD== Following the model of his Pitching NERD, Team NERD tries to give a quantitative value to the aesthetic value of each of the 30 baseball teams. For factors it accounts for "Age," "Park-Adjusted weighted Runs Above Average (wRAA)," "Park-Adjusted Home Run per Fly Ball (HR/FB)," "Team Speed," "Bullpen Strength," "Team Defense," "Luck" (Base Runs – Actual Runs Scored), and "Payroll".<ref name="team" />
<math> \text{AGE}z \times 2 + \text{BAT}z + \text{HR}/\text{FB}z + (\text{SBA}z + \text{SBR}z + \text{XBT}z)\times .33 + \text{BL}z + \text{UZR}z + \text{PAY}z + \text{LUCK}</math>
In a recent interview Cistulli admitted that there is a disconnect between [[Tampa Bay Rays|The Rays]] high tNERD rating and low attendance saying that he is considered adding a "park-adjustment" to his formula which would reflect either the stadium itself or "attendance relative to the stadium's capacity"<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.draysbay.com/2010/11/10/1804861/a-q-a-with-carson-cistulli|title=A Q&A with Carson Cistulli|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=Draysbay.com}}</ref> but overall reception of this statistic has been positive<ref>{{cite web|url= http://espn.go.com/sportsnation/chat/_/id/34253/mlb-insider-rob-neyer|title=Chat with Rob Neyer|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=Espn.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://jfwiii.net/2010/08/23/baseruns-spreadsheet-and-team-nerd/|title=Baseruns Spreadsheets and team NERD|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=Jfwiii.net}}</ref> and [[Fangraphs]] started reporting Team NERD in Cistulli's One Night Only columns beginning August 23, 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangraphs.com/blogs/index.php/one-night-only-now-with-team-nerd/|title=One Night Only: Now with Team NERD|accessdate=2010-11-30|publisher=Fangraphs.com}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = New Valby Idrætspark | nickname = | image = | fullname = ''none'' | location = [[Valby]]
[[Copenhagen]]
[[Denmark]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = 2010 ([[Frem]] estimate)
2012 ([[Copenhagen|Municipality]] estimate) | opened = 2016 ([[Frem]] estimate) | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect =[http://www.sla.dk/indexgb.htm SLA] | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Boldklubben Frem]] | seating_capacity = Ca. 10,000 | dimensions = }} '''New Valby Idrætspark'''No official name has been given. is a proposed [[football (soccer)|football]] [[stadium]] to be built in [[Valby]], [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. If built, the stadium would replace [[Valby Idrætspark]], as the home ground for [[Boldklubben Frem]]. In [[2006 in football (soccer)|2006]] the [[Copenhagen Municipality]] predicted that the main stand of the current Valby Idrætspark would last another 5–10 years.{{cite journal |author = Kultur- og Fritidsforvaltningen |title = Forslag til udviklingsplan for københavnske fodboldstadions |version = |publisher = [[Copenhagen Municipality]] |date = November 2006 |url = http://www2.kk.dk/of/dagsorden.nsf/fa48654eb99b0bd5c125685c004679ff/025daefa4c54b771c1257261004f0488/$FILE/Bilag%201_0.pdf |format = pdf |accessdate = 2007-04-21 }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} As of April 2007 major investments in the current stadium are put on hold as a decision on the construction of a new stadium is being awaited. A final decision was expected in April [[2008 in football (soccer)|2008]].{{cite journal |author = Carsten Haurum, Mads Kamp Hansen and Finn Rudaizky |title = Spørgsmål til skriftlig besvarelse stillet den 23. marts 2008 af Finn Rudaizky vedrørende Valby Idrætspark |version = |publisher = [[Copenhagen Municipality]] |date = March 28, 2007 |url = http://www3.kk.dk/upload/politik%20og%20demokrati/byens_styre/sporgemaal_svar/kff/finnrudaizkyomvalbyidrætspark.pdf |format = pdf |accessdate = 2007-04-26 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Hans Hermansen, [[managing director]] of [[BK Frem]], has indicated that according to the plan, the construction of a new stadium should commence no later than 2010.{{cite book | last =Hermansen | first =Hans | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =Sponsorguiden | publisher =[[Boldklubben Frem]] | year =2006 | location = | pages =2 | url =http://www.bkfrem.dk/upload/20060912185304.pdf | doi = | id = }} However the municipality estimated 2012.{{cite journal |author = Kultur- og Fritidsforvaltningen |title = Forslag til udviklingsplan for københavnske fodboldstadions, Bilag 3. Stadionprioriteringer |version = |publisher = [[Copenhagen Municipality]] |date = November 2006 |url = http://www2.kk.dk/of/dagsorden.nsf/fa48654eb99b0bd5c125685c004679ff/3de263e1d8fc00f3c1257261004f0491/$FILE/Underbilag%203.pdf |format = pdf |accessdate = 2007-04-21 }}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[Boldklubben Frem|Frem]] has suggested that it might be completed by 2016.{{cite news | last =Kassinger | first =Jens Chr. | coauthors = | title =Skal vort klubhus give plads for billige boliger... og om udviklingen i Valby Idrætspark? | work =Boldklubben Frem | pages =24–25 | language =Danish | publisher =Boldklubben Frem | date =April 2007 | url =http://www.bkfrem.dk/upload/20070425175328.pdf | accessdate =2007-04-26 }} In January 2016 the [[municipality]] has ordered a renovation of the existing stadium, worth 3 mio €, thus cancelling plans for a new stadium in the near future. The renovation is due ultimo 2017. {{cite web |title=Renovation Awarded |url=http://estatemedia.dk/dk/2016/01/22/alectia-skal-renovere-valby-idraetspark-for-22-mio-kr/ |work=Estate|language=Danish}}{{cite web|url=http://www.licitationen.dk/procurement/view/6723/totalradgivning_i_forbindelse_med_genopretning_af_stadion_valby_idraetspark_rettet|title=Municipality Tender|language=Danish}} ==See also== *[[Valby Idrætspark]] == Footnotes and references == {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{En icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20070507115804/http://www.sla.dk/planlaeg/valbygb.htm Leading proposal at company website] *{{Da icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20070609141506/http://www.bibliotek.kk.dk/bibliotekerne/findbibliotek/val/lokalt/idraetspark/helhedsplan.pdf All proposals for new development of the Valby Idrætspark area] {{Boldklubben Frem}} {{coord missing|Denmark}} {{DEFAULTSORT:New Valby Idraetspark}} [[Category:Boldklubben Frem]] [[Category:Proposed buildings and structures in Denmark]] [[Category:Sport in Valby]] [[Category:Proposed sports venues]] {{Denmark-sports-venue-stub}}

{{infobox baseball team | name = Nishi Nippon Pirates | established = 1950 | color1 = | color2 = | logo = | cap_logo = | league = [[Nippon Professional Baseball]]
* [[Central League]] | former_leagues = | uniform = | retirednumbers = | colors = | nicknames = | former_names = | ballpark = [[Heiwadai Stadium]] | pastparks = | series = | series_champs = | division_champ_type = | division_champs = | owner = ''[[Nishi-Nippon Shimbun]]'' | manager =[[Toshio Kojima (baseball)|Toshio Kojima]] | gm = | current = }} The {{Nihongo|'''Nishi-Nippon Pirates'''|西日本パイレーツ|Nishi-Nippon Pairētsu}} were a [[Nippon Professional Baseball|Japanese]] baseball team and a founding member of the [[Central League]] in 1950. The team was owned by the ''[[Nishi-Nippon Shimbun]]'' and played their home games in [[Heiwadai Stadium]] in [[Fukuoka]]. The team existed for one season — they placed sixth in 1950, and the following season merged with the also [[Fukuoka]]-based [[Nishitetsu Clippers]] to form the [[Nishitetsu Lions]]. [[Category:Baseball teams in Japan]] [[Category:Defunct baseball teams in Japan]] [[Category:Baseball teams established in 1950]] {{japan-baseball-team-stub}}

{{other uses|Otkritie (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox stadium | image = Stadium Spartak in Moscow (cropped).jpg | image_size = 300px | stadium_name = Otkritie Arena | nickname = | caption = '''[[UEFA Elite stadium|UEFA]]''' {{rating|4|4}} |location = Volokolamskoye sh. 69, Moscow |construction_cost = 14 billion [[Ruble|RUB]]
(200 million [[Euro]])
(430 million USD){{cite web |url=http://itar-tass.com/sport/859160 |title= Леонид Федун: общая стоимость строительства "Открытие-арены" составила 14 млрд рублей|date=26 December 2013 |agency= [[Information Telegraph Agency of Russia]]|accessdate=26 December 2013}} |seating_capacity = 44,307 ([[Russian Premier League]]){{cite web |url=https://eng.premierliga.ru/stadiums/stadiums_1744.html |title=Otkritie Arena}}
44,190 (2018 FIFA World Cup){{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/destination/stadiums/stadium=5030706/index.html |title=Spartak Stadium |publisher=FIFA |access-date=15 June 2018}} |tenants = [[FC Spartak Moscow]] (2014–present)
[[Russia national football team]] (selected matches) | publictransit = {{MOSMETRO-bull|7|}} [[Spartak (Moscow Metro)|Spartak]] | broke_ground = October 2010 |coordinates ={{Coord|55|49|4.3|N|37|26|24.9|E|region:RU-MOW_type:landmark|display=title,inline}} |opened = 5 September 2014 |dimensions = 105 × 68 m |surface = Grass |architect = BiznesTehProekt, PozhEvroStroi |website = {{URL|otkritiearena.ru/en}} }} '''Otkritie Arena''' ({{lang-rus|"Открытие Арена"|p=ɐtˈkrɨtʲɪjə ɐˈrʲenə}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in Moscow, Russia. The venue is used mostly for [[association football|football]] matches, hosting the home matches of [[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]] and occasionally the [[Russia national football team|Russian national team]]. It is called '''Spartak Stadium''' during the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup]]{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/confederationscup/destination/cities/city=1559/index.html|title=FIFA Confederations Cup Russia 2017 - Moscow - FIFA|last=FIFA.com|publisher=FIFA}} and [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].[https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y=2015/m=10/news=stadium-names-for-the-2018-fifa-world-cup-russiatm-confirmed-2709881.html Stadium names for the 2018 FIFA World Cup Russia™ confirmed]. [[FIFA]]. The stadium is designed with a capacity of 45,360 people. "Otkritie Arena", named after the sponsor [[Otkritie Holding]], is the commercial name for the Spartak Stadium until 2019.[http://spartak.com/main/news/35863/ «СПАРТАК» И «ОТКРЫТИЕ» ЗАКЛЮЧИЛИ СПОНСОРСКОЕ СОГЛАШЕНИЕ] ==History== [[File:Match veteranov Spartaka (27).jpg|thumb|250px|left|Starostin brothers monument]] [[File:Match veteranov Spartaka (6).jpg|thumb|left|250px|Square near Otkrytiye Arena]] [[File:Match veteranov Spartaka (10).jpg|thumb|left|250px|Otkrytiye Arena inside]] The groundbreaking ceremony was held on 2 July 2007, but construction was delayed multiple times for different reasons. Construction was scheduled to be completed between 2009 and 2010 but, as of 2009, the stadium was still in the design stage. In 2010, the stadium project underwent revision because it was rejected by an architectural council that found the project too ordinary. The current design was developed by [[AECOM]], in association with Sport Concepts, and façade designer, Dexter Moren Associates adjacent to a separate indoor arena.{{cite web |url=http://www.aecom.com/What+We+Do/Building+Engineering/_carousel/Стадион+«Спартак»?languagehoice=ru_RU&Go=Go&localeHidden=ru_RU&localeFlash=en_US |title=Article|website=''aecom.com''}} The main financing of the construction came from the club's owner [[Leonid Fedun]] through affiliated companies [[LUKoil]] company and IFD Kapital. With the construction of the stadium in 2015, the [[Moscow Metro]] station [[Spartak (Moscow Metro)|Spartak]], which had been completed in 1975, opened for passenger traffic. On 19 February 2013 it was announced that the new stadium will be named "Otkrytiye Arena" for six years under the terms of the contract with [[Otkrytiye (bank)|Otkrytiye Bank]]. On 21 August 2014, a monument to the [[Starostin brothers]], the founders of [[FC Spartak Moscow]], opened near the north stands inside the stadium. A 24.5-meter sculpture of the [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] [[Gladiator]] [[Spartacus]], for whom the club is named, was unveiled in the square outside the stadium. The stadium officially opened on 5 September 2014. Spartak played against [[Red Star Belgrade]] and drew 1–1, with [[Dmitri Kombarov]] scoring the first goal for Spartak at the new stadium after a free-kick. The stadium was constructed on the site of the [[Tushino Airport]]. The new stadium was included in [[Russian 2018 FIFA World Cup bid|Russia's bid]] for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]], hosting the opening game, with [[Luzhniki Stadium]] slated to host the final.[http://www.worldinteriordesignnetwork.com/news/russias_vtb_arena_to_be_the_main_venue_for_2018_fifa_world_cup_101206/ «Russia’s VTB Arena to be the main venue for 2018 FIFA World Cup] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707133157/http://www.worldinteriordesignnetwork.com/news/russias_vtb_arena_to_be_the_main_venue_for_2018_fifa_world_cup_101206/ |date=7 July 2011 }} The stadium was completed ahead of [[VTB Arena]], which originally was planned for the World Cup opener. It was also one of four stadiums used for the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup]]. Artists such as [[Incubus (band)|Incubus]], [[Triggerfinger]] ([[Park Live Festival|Park Live 2015]]) have all performed at the stadium. Available at the stadium are navigation assistance from volunteers, storage rooms, registration of children, lost and found office. Two sectors with 50 seats each are available for people with disabilities. This part of the arena is furnished with ramps and elevators.{{Cite news|url=http://tass.ru/sport/580006|title=На стадионе футбольного клуба "Спартак" для инвалидов будут выделены два сектора по 50 |format=PDF |date=3 July 2018 |access-date=3 July 2018}} |} == Concerts == * 15 July 2017 – [[Depeche Mode]] – [[Global Spirit Tour]] * 13 July 2018 – [[Guns N' Roses]] – [[Not in This Lifetime... Tour]] * 19 July 2019 – [[Ed Sheeran]] – [[÷ Tour]] == Security == In preparation for the 2018 FIFA World Cup, the stadium was outfitted with video surveillance and fan identification systems and screening equipment. Security measures have been developed by the 2018 World Cup Local Organising Committee, Ministry of Internal Affairs and Federal Security Service in collaboration with the stadium services.{{Cite web|url=http://www.secuteck.ru/articles2/event/komfort-bezopasnost-vysokiy-uroven-meropriyatiyctadion-spartak-gotovitsya-k-chm-2018/|title=Комфорт + безопасность = высокий уровень мероприятийCтадион "Спартак" готовится к ЧМ-2018|website=secuteck.ru|access-date=14 June 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{Official website|otkritiearena.ru}} * [http://spartak.com/main/8639/8642/ Section on the official site of Spartak about the stadium with renders of the stadium] * [http://spartak.com/main/13/8645/ Article on the official website of Spartak with pictures of the current design of the stadium as of December 2010] {{FC Spartak Moscow}} {{Russian Premier League venues}} {{2017 FIFA Confederations Cup}} {{2018 FIFA World Cup stadiums}} [[Category:FC Spartak Moscow]] [[Category:Football venues in Russia]] [[Category:Sports venues in Moscow]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Russia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2014]] [[Category:2018 FIFA World Cup stadiums]] [[Category:2017 FIFA Confederations Cup stadiums]] [[Category:2014 establishments in Russia]]

page.title: Saint Kitts & Nevis Amateur Athletic Association

revision.text:
{{Infobox sport governing body |name = Saint Kitts & Nevis Amateur Athletic Association |abbrev = SKNAAA |logo = Saint Kitts & Nevis Amateur Athletic Association Logo.png |logosize = 250px |sport = [[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]] |category = |image = |caption = |jurisdiction = Association |founded = {{Start date|1961}} |aff = [[IAAF]] |affdate = {{Start date|1978}} |region = [[North American, Central American and Caribbean Athletic Association|NACAC]] |regionyear = |headquarters = [[Basseterre]] |location = |president = [[Glenville Jeffers]] |chairman = |chairperson = |chair = |chiefexec = |vicepresident = [[Val Henry]] |secretary = [[Francil Morris]] |coach = |womenscoach = |key staff = |operating income = |sponsor = |year closed = |replaced = Saint Kitts Amateur Athletic and Cycling Association |prevfounded = |url = www.sknaaa.com |countryflag = Saint Kitts and Nevis |countryflag2 = |countryflag3 = }}
The '''Saint Kitts & Nevis Amateur Athletic Association''' ('''SKNAAA''') is the governing body for the sport of athletics in [[Saint Kitts and Nevis]].<ref name=iaaf_1> {{ Citation | last = | first = | date = | title = Saint Kitts & Nevis Amateur Athletic Association | url = http://www.iaaf.org/about-iaaf/structure/member-federations/northcentral-americac#SKN | publisher = [[IAAF]] | page = | language = | accessdate = January 4, 2013 }} </ref>
==History== SKNAAA was founded in 1961.<ref> {{ Citation | last = Matthews | first = Peter | date = | title = Historical Dictionary of Track and Field | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=kh97OBEUTn4C&pg=PA192&lpg=PA192&dq=Historical+Dictionary+of+Track+and+Field+nevis&source=bl&ots=Tl4O9XL7Jh&sig=k3F9a3s2UaAedjBQrGEp-f7-hIg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=87V5UMOeFsnPsgatuYGgCg&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Historical%20Dictionary%20of%20Track%20and%20Field%20nevis&f=false | publisher = | page = 192 | language = | accessdate = October 13, 2012 }} </ref> After separating from the Saint Kitts Amateur Athletic and Cycling Association in 1977,<ref name=sknaaa_1> {{ Citation| last =| first =| date =| title =About SKNAAA| url =http://www.sknaaa.com/about.asp| publisher =Saint Kitts & Nevis Amateur Athletic Association| page =| language =| accessdate =October 13, 2012| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20120830202609/http://www.sknaaa.com/about.asp| archivedate =August 30, 2012| df =}} </ref> SKNAAA was affiliated to the [[IAAF]] in 1978.<ref name=iaaf_2> {{ Citation | last = | first = | date = | title = ASOCIACIÓN INTERNACIONAL DE FEDERACIONES DE ATLETISMO - CONSTITUCIÓN EN VIGOR A PARTIR DEL 1 DE NOVIEMBRE DE 2011 | url = http://www.iaaf.org/mm/Document/06/28/25/62825_PDF_Spanish.pdf | publisher = [[IAAF]] | page = 60 | language = Spanish | accessdate = October 13, 2012 }} </ref>
Current president is [[Glenville Jeffers]]. He was elected in December 2009<ref name=nacac_1> {{ Citation | last = NACAC Newsletter, Bulletin December 2009, Volume 2, Edition 4 | first = | date = | title = SKNAAA elects new Executive/SKNAA Elige una Nueva Ejecutiva | url = http://www.athleticsnacac.org/attachments/article/114/NewsletterDec09.pdf | publisher = [[North American, Central American and Caribbean Athletic Association|NACAC]] | page = 13 | language = | accessdate = January 4, 2013 }} </ref> and re-elected in January 2014.<ref name=sknvibes_01> {{ Citation | last = | first = | date = January 13, 2014 | title = SKNAAA General Body elects new Executive Committee at 2nd Quadrennial | url = http://www.sknvibes.com/news/newsdetails.cfm/83847 | publisher = SKNVibes | page = | language = | accessdate = January 22, 2014 }} </ref>
==Affiliations== SKNAAA is the national member federation for [[Saint Kitts and Nevis]] in the following international organisations: *[[International Association of Athletics Federations]] (IAAF) *[[North American, Central American and Caribbean Athletic Association]] (NACAC) *[[Association of Panamerican Athletics]] (APA) *[[Central American and Caribbean Athletic Confederation]] (CACAC) *[[Leeward_Islands_Championships_in_Athletics#Leeward_Islands_Athletics_Association|Leeward Islands Athletic Association]] (LIAA)<sup>†</sup> <sup>†</sup>: The [[Nevis Amateur Athletic Association]] (NAAA) is separately affiliated to the LIAA.<ref name=naaa_1> {{ Citation | last = | first = | date = June 2, 2002 | title = CONSTITUTION OF THE LEEWARD ISLANDS ATHLETIC ASSOCIATION (LIAA) | url = https://sites.google.com/site/nevisaaa/liaaconstitution | publisher = [[Nevis Amateur Athletic Association]] | page = | language = | accessdate = October 13, 2012 }} </ref>
Moreover, it is part of the following national organisations: *[[Saint Kitts and Nevis Olympic Committee]] (SKNOC)
==National records== SKNAAA maintains the [[Saint Kitts and Nevis records in athletics]].
==External links== *[http://www.sknaaa.com/ Official website] *[http://www.facebook.com/StKNAAA SKNAAA on facebook]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{Sports governing bodies in Saint Kitts and Nevis}} {{National Members of the International Association of Athletics Federations}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Saint Kitts and Nevis Amateur Athletic Association}} [[Category:National members of the North American, Central American and Caribbean Athletic Association]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Saint Kitts and Nevis|Amateur Athletic Association]] [[Category:National governing bodies for athletics]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 1961]] [[Category:Sports associations]]
