revision.text:
[[File:VIRAT KHOLI (16005618260).jpg|thumb|'Off the field I am good friends with them (Australian cricketers) but on the field it is a competition' - Indian cricketer [[Virat Kohli]], who has sledged Australia on numerous occasions.]] {{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} '''Sledging''' is a term used in [[cricket]] to describe the practice whereby some players seek to gain an advantage by [[insulting]] or verbally [[intimidating]] the opposing player. The purpose is to try to weaken the opponent's concentration, thereby causing them to make mistakes or underperform.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/bitesize/articles/z683qp3 |title=The origins of cricket jargon |work=BBC Bitesize |accessdate=17 November 2018}}</ref> It can be effective because the batsman stands within hearing range of the [[Bowler (cricket)|bowler]] and certain close [[fielding (cricket)|fielders]]; and ''vice versa''. The insults may be direct or feature in conversations among fielders designed to be overheard. The term has also been used in other sports, as when the tennis player [[Nick Kyrgios]] [[Nick Kyrgios#Controversies|insulted his opponent]], [[Stan Wawrinka]], by referring to a purported encounter between another player and the latter's girlfriend.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ravi |last=Ubha |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/08/13/tennis/kyrgios-wawrinka-tennis-sledge-montreal/index.html |title=Nick Kyrgios said what?! Aussie slammed, then fined, for lewd sledge |publisher=CNN |date=13 August 2015 }}</ref>
There is debate in the cricketing world as to whether this constitutes poor [[sportsmanship]] or good-humoured banter.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/7244667.stm BBC Sport: ''India board proposes sledging ban''. Retrieved on 2 November 2008.]</ref> Sledging is sometimes interpreted as [[abuse]], and it is acknowledged some comments aimed as sledges do sometimes cross the line into [[personal abuse]], however, this is not always the case. Sledging can sometimes be a humorous attempt at distraction. Former Australian [[Australian cricket captains|captain]] [[Steve Waugh]] referred to the practice as 'mental disintegration'.<ref>{{cite news |first=Steve|last=Waugh|url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/in-this-extract-from-his-new-book-steve-waugh-explains-his-strategy-of-mental-disintegration/news-story/b24993a76add04d7ee9050bfa8d1efc3|title=In this extract from his new book, Steve Waugh explains his strategy of mental disintegration|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|date=30 November 2013|accessdate=6 July 2018}}</ref>
==Origin== [[File:Shane Warne 2011 cropped.jpg|thumb|'Sledging is an effective cricketing weapon' - Australian cricketer [[Shane Warne]], who revealed that he sledged to charge up himself.]] Australian newspapers acknowledged "sledging" as a term in the mid-1970s.<ref>{{cite news|title=Our turn to be bounced!|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=J-BUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=R5IDAAAAIBAJ&dq=sledging&pg=3314%2C3201920|accessdate=10 February 2013|newspaper=The Age|date=17 January 1977}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=O'Reilly|first=Bill|title=Sportsmanship given a terrible hiding|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6Z9WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=U-cDAAAAIBAJ&dq=sledging&pg=2751%2C4288214|accessdate=10 February 2013|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=16 February 1979}}</ref> Despite the relatively recent coining of the term, the practice is as old as cricket itself, with historical accounts of witty banter between players being quite common. [[W. G. Grace]] and his brother [[E. M. Grace|E. M.]] were noted throughout their careers for being "noisy and boisterous" on the field. W. G. admitted that they used to "chaff" (i.e., tease) opponents, and this is seen as part of the [[gamesmanship]] for which E. M. and W. G. were always controversial.<ref name="Rae19">Rae, p.19.</ref>
According to [[Ian Chappell]], the use of "sledging" as a term originated at [[Adelaide Oval]] in either the 1963–1964 or 1964–1965 [[Sheffield Shield]] competition. Chappell claims that a cricketer who swore in the presence of a woman was said to have reacted to an incident "like a sledgehammer". As a result, the direction of insults or obscenities at opponents became known as "sledging".<ref>Graham Seal, ''The Lingo: Listening to Australian English'' (University of New South Wales Press, 1999, {{ISBN|0-86840-680-5}}): page 141.</ref>
According to the [[BBC]]’s [[Pat Murphy (sports journalist)|Pat Murphy]]: “My understanding is that it came from the mid-sixties and a guy called [[Grahame Corling]], who used to open the bowling for [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] and [[Australian cricket team|Australia]] … apparently the suggestion was that this guy's wife was [having an affair] with another team-mate, and when he came into bat [the fielding team] started singing [[When a Man Loves a Woman (Percy Sledge song)|When a Man Loves A Woman]], the old [[Percy Sledge]] number.”<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/episode/b00lmytk/Yes_its_the_Ashes_11_07_2009 BBC Radio 5Live, ‘Yes it's the Ashes’, 11 July 2009]{{expired link|date=September 2016}}</ref> [[File:BEN STOKES (11704837023).jpg|thumb|'I don't have anger issues' - English cricketer [[Ben Stokes]] who has been involved in several confrontations with Australia.]] The [[Australian cricket team in Australia in 1974-75|1974–75 Australians]] were labelled the ''Ugly Australians'' for their hard-nosed cricket, verbal abuse and hostile fast bowling. "Behind the batsmen, [[Rod Marsh]] and his captain [[Ian Chappell]] would vie with each other in profanity",<ref>p119, [[Bob Willis]] and Patrick Murphy, ''Starting With Grace, A Pictorial Celebration of Cricket 1864–1986'', Stanley Paul, 1986</ref> and [[Tom Graveney]] wrote "It was an open secret that [[Ian Chappell|he]] used to encourage his players to give a lot of verbal abuse to rival batsman when they were at the wicket in an attempt to break their concentration."<ref>pp116-117, [[Tom Graveney]] and Norman Miller, ''The Ten Greatest Test Teams'', Sidgewick and Jackson, 1988</ref>
West Indian batsman [[Viv Richards]] was notorious for punishing bowlers that dared to sledge him. So much so, that many opposing captains banned their players from the practice. However, in a county game against [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club|Glamorgan]], [[Greg Thomas]] attempted to sledge him after he had played and missed at several balls in a row. He informed Richards: "It's red, round and weighs about five ounces, in case you were wondering." Richards hammered the next delivery out of the cricket grounds and into the nearby river Taff. Turning to the bowler, he commented: "Greg, you know what it looks like, now go and find it."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/funny_old_game/3068365.stm Lighter examples of sledging – BBC Sport]</ref>
==International Views==
=== Australia === It has been pointed out that the Australian cricket team believes in playing in a more 'robust' fashion than others and that it upholds a 'sledging culture'.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/sport/cricket/australias-sledging-culture-needs-to-be-addressed-20171209-h01quw.html|title=Australia's sledging culture needs to be addressed|last=Lane|first=Tim|date=2017-12-09|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> Australian bowler [[Merv Hughes]] has claimed that he credits sledging for twenty-five percent of the wickets he has taken.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/article-63591/It-sledging-gone-far-McMillan-stormed-wielding-gun.html|title=It seemed my sledging had gone too far when McMillan stormed in wielding a gun|work=Mail Online|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref> As per Australian cricketer [[Mark Taylor (cricketer)|Mark Taylor]], Australian fans want to watch 'combative cricket'.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/cricket/david-warner-sledging-pakistans-wasim-akram-englands-ian-bell-play-down-rohit-sharma-incident/news-story/652eeb5094d11da8816eaa6ad77e770e|title=David Warner sledging: Pakistan’s Wasim Akram, England’s Ian Bell play down Rohit Sharma incident|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Australian batsman [[Ricky Ponting]] has argued that sledging helps get players 'out of control' and 'out of their comfort zone'. Ponting has also said that it's 'not as bad' as the average person would think.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cricket.com.au/news/ricky-ponting-ashes-sledging-australia-england-adelaide-oval-second-test-james-anderson/2017-12-03|title=Ponting's insight into value of 'banter'|work=cricket.com.au|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en}}</ref> Australian spinner [[Shane Warne]] describes sledging as an 'effective cricketing weapon'.<ref name=":3" /> On [[Allan Border]]'s advice, Warne has also adopted sledging as a technique to 'switch on' for a contest.<ref name=":3" /> Australian all-rounder [[Michael Clarke (cricketer)|Michael Clarke]] has said that he 'loved the aggressive approach'.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/cricket/85995702/no-need-for-excessive-sledging--michael-clarke-and-brad-haddin|title=No need for excessive sledging - Michael Clarke and Brad Haddin|website=Stuff|language=en|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref> In response to 'personal sledging' accusations against his team, Australian cricketer [[Steve Smith (cricketer)|Steve Smith]] has said, "Getting personal on the field is not on, that's crossing the line in my opinion."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cricket.com.au/news/steve-smith-personal-sledging-comments-australia-south-africa-first-test-warner-de-kock-du-plessis/2018-03-05|title=Smith, Proteas at odds over 'personal' sledging|work=cricket.com.au|access-date=2018-07-02|language=en}}</ref> By contrast, Australian opener [[Ed Cowan]] suggests that 'all sledging is personal' adding that Australian cricketers should be 'nowhere near the line'.<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/inquirer/warner-outburst-shows-shifting-line-on-cricket-sledging/news-story/13bb0dd7ec565a7e861f0ab1f6670255|title=Aussies never ‘cross the line’|last=|first=|date=|website=www.theaustralian.com.au|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref>
Before the controversial Test series during [[Australian cricket team in South Africa in 2017–18|Australia's Tour of South Africa in 2018]] commenced, Australian spinner [[Nathan Lyon]] commented on sledging: "We know where the line is. We headbutt it, but we don’t go over it."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news.com.au/sport/cricket/blurred-lines-where-exactly-does-the-line-lie-in-modern-cricket/news-story/8b1f340a24a1fe0bd6e1f8315b931008|title=Where’s the ‘line’ in dark art of sledging|work=NewsComAu|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref> Following the [[2018 Australian ball-tampering scandal]], voices calling for a reformation of Australia's 'cricket culture' have emerged.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/cricket/103584100/sledging-has-a-place-in-cricket-says-new-australian-coach-justin-langer|title=Sledging has a place in cricket, says new Australian coach Justin Langer|website=Stuff|language=en|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref> Australian Prime Minister [[Malcolm Turnbull|Malcom Turnbull]] called for an end to sledging following the scandal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/sport/cricket/australia-pm-malcolm-turnbull-calls-for-end-to-sledging-in-cricket-after-ball-tampering-row-1.716431|title=Australia PM Malcolm Turnbull calls for end to sledging in cricket after ball tampering row|work=The National|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en}}</ref> Following the outrage over the scandal, former Australian cricketer [[Justin Langer]] said that cricket would be 'dull' without sledging. Australian batsman [[David Warner (cricketer)|David Warner]] who received a one-year ban following the controversial series, exclaimed: "I play with aggression on the field and I try not to cross that line".<ref name=":9" /> Former Australian cricketer and former coach of the Australian team [[Darren Lehmann]] has suggested that Australia is 'not as bad' as portrayed, adding that sledging was worse during his own times.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://dailytimes.com.pk/277218/australia-not-as-bad-as-portrayed-sledging-was-worse-during-my-time-lehmann/|title=Australia not as bad as portrayed, sledging was worse during my time: Lehmann - Daily Times|date=2018-08-03|work=Daily Times|access-date=2018-08-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Bangladesh === Historically described as a 'timid' side, Bangladesh underwent a transformation as they grew in confidence following the [[2015 Cricket World Cup]], according to Bangladeshi cricketer [[Mashrafe Mortaza]]. Mortaza says that he encourages his players to 'look the opponent in the eye' while 'not overstepping a line'. He also insists that his side 'does not start a conversation' on the field. Bangladesh former cricketer and commentator [[Athar Ali Khan]] says that Bangladesh has moved out of a 'culture of backing off'.<ref name=":1" />
=== England === England coach [[Trevor Bayliss]] expressed disapproval over sledging being caught on the stump mics, suggesting that sledging must be censored on television as it isn't a 'great thing for young kids at home watching'.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-12-04/ashes-sledging-should-be-censored-on-tv-bayliss-says/9222352|title=Escalating Ashes sledging should be censored on TV, England coach says|date=2017-12-04|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-08-16|language=en-AU}}</ref> England wicketkeeper [[Jonny Bairstow]] has expressed a need for greater clarity with regard to what is 'personal', pointing out that there are so many grey areas around the 'line'.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sport24.co.za/Cricket/bairstow-calls-for-clear-sledging-guidelines-20180309|title=Bairstow calls for clear sledging guidelines|work=Sport|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en}}</ref> Before [[English cricket team in New Zealand in 2017–18|England's Tour of New Zealand in 2018]], former English cricketer [[Geoffrey Boycott]] called for English cricketers to 'drop' sledging.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.odt.co.nz/sport/cricket/calls-england-drop-sledging|title=Calls for England to drop sledging|date=2018-03-21|work=Otago Daily Times Online News|access-date=2018-09-14|language=en}}</ref>
=== India === [[Sourav Ganguly|Saurav Ganguly]] is known to be among India's first 'aggressive' captains who employed sledging on the field.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.quirkybyte.com/blog/2016/07/indias-aggressive-captain-sourav-ganguly/|title=India’s most aggressive captain- Sourav Ganguly - QuirkyByte|date=2016-07-11|work=QuirkyByte|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref> Indian batsman [[Virender Sehwag]] has said, "If there's no sledging, there won't be any enjoyment left in the game."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://zeenews.india.com/cricket/virender-sehwag-backs-virat-kohlis-aggressive-captaincy-says-sledging-can-be-fun-2037952.html|title=Virender Sehwag backs Virat Kohli's aggressive captaincy, says sledging can be fun|date=2017-08-30|work=Zee News|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> Indian cricketer [[Gautam Gambhir]] said it's fine to do 'whatever you can to upset the opposition till the time you don't get personal.'<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news18.com/cricketnext/news/sledging-part-of-the-game-getting-personal-is-not-gautam-gambhir-1362823.html|title=Sledging Part of the Game, Getting Personal is Not: Gautam Gambhir|date=2017-03-22|work=News18|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/cricket/gautam-gambhir-says-sledge-but-don-t-cross-the-boundary/story-9gBsDXkCkP6clLEBXu4OKL.html|title=Gautam Gambhir says sledge, but don’t cross the boundary|date=2017-03-21|work=Hindustan Times|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en}}</ref> Indian wicketkeeper [[MS Dhoni]] has described sledging as an 'art' and has said it is fair as long as a 'line' isn't crossed.<ref>Outlook Magazine. 10 March 2008. https://books.google.com.au/books?id=UzEEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA88&lpg=PA88&dq=dhoni+on+sledging&source=bl&ots=Hn8hZz7kAZ&sig=1PIjcCcJkVTl6V2asOJGAHJs_pE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj5ju-00NjbAhXDybwKHUuUD7E4ChDoAQhQMAg#v=onepage&q=dhoni%20on%20sledging&f=false</ref> Indian pacer [[S. Sreesanth|Sreesanth]] has said that sledging is 'part and parcel' of the game.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/cricket/story/_/id/22894978/sledging-part-parcel-game-sreesanth|title='Sledging is part and parcel of game' - Sreesanth|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref> Indian bowler [[Irfan Pathan]] has said that sledging has a 'certain charm' about it also adding that it should be done 'within limits'.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news18.com/cricketnext/news/sledging-within-limit-fine-with-irfan-544491.html|title=Sledging within limit fine with Irfan|date=2008-02-14|work=News18|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> Indian legend [[Sachin Tendulkar]] has called for sledging within 'certain limits' in his autobiography [[Playing It My Way]].<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.sportskeeda.com/cricket/sledging-in-cricket-drawing-a-fine-line-between-aggression-and-argument|title=Sledging in Cricket: Drawing a fine line between aggression and argument|date=2018-03-23|access-date=2018-07-12}}</ref> Former Indian cricketer and commentator [[Sunil Gavaskar]] explains that sledging is done to 'disrupt a cricketer's concentration'.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/cricket/bangladesh-cricket-team-transform-from-cubs-to-tigers-in-art-of-sledging/story-jahMkgdBBakyJpaOJeIaoO.html|title=Bangladesh cricket team transform from cubs to tigers in art of sledging|date=2017-09-07|work=Hindustan Times|access-date=2018-06-18|language=en}}</ref> Former Indian wicketkeeper [[Mohammad Kaif]] excalimed that sledging is fine but verbals must not extend to 'family'.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/panache/mohammad-kaif-sledging-within-limits-is-fine-but-family-should-be-kept-out/articleshow/63279035.cms|title=Mohammad Kaif: Sledging within limits is fine, but family should be kept out|last=Rebello|first=Maleeva|date=2018-03-13|work=The Economic Times|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref>
Indian cricket captain [[Virat Kohli]] said, "We take it very well and we give it back even better."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://au.sports.yahoo.com/ed-cowan-reveals-inappropriate-virat-kohli-sledge-australia-v-india-cricket-34867155.html|title='I wanted to pick up the stump and stab him'|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en-AU}}</ref> Ganguly has stated that Kohli's aggression is 'two-times more' than his own.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/cricket/here-s-what-sourav-ganguly-had-to-say-about-virat-kohli-s-aggression/story-RawwscsHl6ZoM4OQ6eyKaL.html|title=Why aggressive Virat Kohli ‘two-times more’ better than Sourav Ganguly|date=2016-12-14|work=Hindustan Times|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en}}</ref> Under Kohli's captaincy, players are required to have 'top fitness, high intensity and an aggressive mindset'.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/cricket/indian-cricket-team-under-virat-kohli-has-a-new-culture-fall-in-line-or-else/story-mQCA2hSfv9M3GUsRifNN9N.html|title=Indian cricket team under Virat Kohli has a new ‘culture’- fall in line or else|last=|first=|date=2018-03-01|work=Hindustan Times|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en}}</ref> [[Sachin Tendulkar]] has pointed out that aggression has become the strength of the Indian team under Kohli.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-vs-new-zealand-2017/sachin-tendulkar-believes-virat-kohli-s-aggression-has-become-india-s-strength/story-FRiUZ6beOmFh4Y6q6cYopO.html|title=Virat Kohli’s aggression has become India’s strength, says Sachin Tendulkar|last=|first=|date=2017-10-23|work=Hindustan Times|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en}}</ref> Indian Test cricketer [[Cheteshwar Pujara]] said that he makes 'a lot of noise on the field' and believes that sledging 'helps the bowlers'.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cricket.com.au/news/cheteshwar-pujara-virat-kohli-sledging-india-team-art-tricks-sri-lanka-test-series/2017-08-09|title=Pujara 'learning the tricks of sledging'|work=cricket.com.au|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en}}</ref> Indian batsman [[Ajinkya Rahane]] has compared sledging (on the cricket field) to 'car honking while driving'.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.firstpost.com/firstcricket/sports-news/india-batsman-ajinkya-rahane-says-hes-against-on-field-sledging-compares-it-to-car-honking-4401791.html|title=India batsman Ajinkya Rahane says he's against on-field sledging; compares it to 'car honking'- Firstcricket News, Firstpost|website=FirstCricket|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref>
=== Pakistan === Pakistani cricketer [[Imran Khan]] has mentioned that his players 'learnt' aggression during Pakistan's 1972-73 tour of Australia. Khan specifically mentioned [[Sarfraz Nawaz|Sarfaraz Nawaz]] among the players that 'picked up sledging' from the Australians.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2016/dec/14/australia-and-pakistans-cricket-history-a-rare-object-of-mutual-fascination|title=Australia and Pakistan's cricket history a rare object of mutual fascination {{!}} Russell Jackson|last=Jackson|first=Russell|date=2016-12-14|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref> In 1999, the [[Pakistan Cricket Board]] lodged an official complaint to its Australian counterpart over 'persistent sledging' and the use of 'highly abusive language' against Pakistani players.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/78714.html|title=Pakistan shows concern over Aussies sledging|work=Cricinfo|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en}}</ref> Before Pakistan's Tour of Australia in 2004, then Pakistani captain [[Inzamam-ul-Haq]] made it clear that his players will 'give what they get' if subjected to sledging.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2004-11-29/well-sledge-you-right-back-warns-inzamam/594262|title=We'll sledge you right back, warns Inzamam|date=2004-11-29|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en-AU}}</ref> Pakistani paceman [[Wasim Akram]] has emphasised that what is said on the field should remain on the field.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sport360.com/article/cricket/international-cricket/271516/warner-de-kock-row-pakistan-great-wasim-akram-says-what-happens-on-the-field-should-stay-on-it|title=Warner-De Kock row: Pakistan great Wasim Akram says what happens on the field should stay on it - Article - Sport360|website=sport360.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref>
=== South Africa === South African skipper [[Faf du Plessis|Faf Du Plessis]] remarked that "If showing aggression is considered a breach of conduct, we could rather have bowling machines bowl to a batsman."<ref name=":7" />
=== Sri Lanka === The [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lankan Cricket Team]] has had a reputation of avoiding verbal aggression.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/sri-lanka-v-india-2015/content/story/908499.html|title=Aggression never about verbals or sledging - Sangakkara|work=Cricinfo|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> Former Sri Lankan captain [[Arjuna Ranatunga]] called for a ban on sledging in early 2008 with particular reference to Australia's interactions with touring sides.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.adelaidenow.com.au/sport/cricket/ban-all-sledging-arjuna/news-story/25fe23fa8116ecd6f1b8af21a814d20a|title=Ban all sledging: Arjuna|date=2008-01-28|language=en|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref> Former Sri Lankan wicketkeeper [[Kumar Sangakkara]] drew a clear distinction between aggression 'on the field' and verbal sledging, remarking that the two are different from each other.<ref name=":6" />
=== West Indies === The [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies Cricket Team]] is known to have had 'feared pace attacks' during the 1980s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://theconversation.com/its-time-for-cricket-to-clean-up-its-sledging-excesses-20736|title=It's time for cricket to clean up its sledging excesses|last=Hancock|first=Nigel|work=The Conversation|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en}}</ref> According to West Indies great [[Viv Richards]], sledging is an 'inevitable part' of modern-day cricket. Richards further expounds that 'racial' slurring translates to crossing the line, comparing it to 'being hit in the nuts' and asserting that it is unacceptable.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/sledging-inevitable-and-here-to-stay-says-west-indies-legend-viv-richards|title=Sledging inevitable and here to stay, says West Indies legend Viv Richards|work=SBS News|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==Sledging incidents== {| class="wikitable" |+ Recorded incidents !Players Involved !Date !Match !Part of !Description |- |[[Dennis Lillee]] and [[Javed Miandad]] |November 16, 1981 |{{Flag|Australia}} vs {{Flag|Pakistan}} |[[Pakistani cricket team in Australia in 1981–82|Pakistani Cricket Team in Australia in 1981-82]] |Australian bowler [[Dennis Lillee]] and Pakistani batsman [[Javed Miandad]] were involved in a collision following which the former kicked the Pakistani's bottom. Miandad responded by threatening to strike Lillee with the bat.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/486739.html|title='One of the most undignified incidents in Test history'|work=Cricinfo|access-date=2018-08-23|language=en}}</ref> |- |[[Allan Border]] and [[Robin Smith (cricketer)|Robin Smith]] |August 10–14, 1989 |{{Flag|England}} vs {{Flag|Australia}} |[[Australian cricket team in England in 1989|Australian Cricket Team in England in 1989]] |When England cricketer [[Robin Smith (cricketer)|Robin Smith]] asked for a drink, Australia's [[Allan Border]] bursted out: "What do you think this is, a fucking tea party? No, you can’t have a fucking glass of water, you can fucking wait like the rest of us.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.news.com.au/sport/the-ashes-2015-australia-and-englands-greatest-ashes-sledges/news-story/762252c18e2c632815b38f672bb56a08|title=Greatest sledges in Ashes history|work=NewsComAu|access-date=2018-06-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/sport/getting-tough-the-1989-ashes/news-story/69fe4cfe3844c2642d33608ecdc1772d?sv=9b6c6517accb69e470c2a2c857627e97|title=Getting tough - the 1989 Ashes|last=|first=|date=|website=Daily Telegraph|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> |- |[[Javed Miandad|Javed Minded]] and [[Merv Hughes|Merv Huges]] |1990 |{{Flag|Australia}} vs {{Flag|Pakistan}} |[[Pakistani cricket team in Australia in 1989–90|Pakistani Cricket Team in Australia in 1989-90]] |One incident, as recalled by [[Merv Hughes]], was when he was bowling to Pakistan batsman [[Javed Miandad]], who informed the overweight bowler that he was "too fat to be playing cricket" and "should be driving buses". After Hughes got Javed caught out, he intercepted him on his way back to the pavilion and said, "ticket please".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/sports/cricket/that-moment-when-merv-hughes-asked-javed-miandad-for-a-bus-ticket-watch-video-4604071/|title=That moment when Merv Hughes asked Javed Miandad for a bus ticket|date=7 April 2017|newspaper=The Indian Express}}</ref> |- |[[Merv Hughes]] and [[Gary Kirsten]] |March 4–8, 1994 |{{Flag|Australia}} vs {{Flag|South Africa}} |[[Australian cricket team in South Africa in 1993–94|Australian Cricket Team in South Africa in 1993-94]] |Australia's [[Merv Hughes]] verbally abused South Africa's [[Gary Kirsten]] and was handed a 2000-pound fine for the same.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/cricket-hughes-handed-suspended-fine-1428673.html|title=Cricket: Hughes handed suspended fine|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en-GB}}</ref> |- |[[Glenn McGrath]] and [[Alan Mullally|Allan Mullally]] |December 29, 1998 |{{Flag|Australia}} vs {{Flag|England}} |[[English cricket team in Australia in 1998–99|English Cricket Team in Australia in 1998-99]] |Australian cricketer [[Glenn McGrath]] had a go at England's [[Alan Mullally|Allan Mullally]] who responded to the Australian's sledging with 'smirks and smiles'.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/74951.html|title=McGrath given suspended fine for sledging in Test (29 December 1998)|work=Cricinfo|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref> |- |[[Sachin Tendulkar]] and [[Glenn McGrath]] |October 7, 2000 |{{Flag|India}} vs {{Flag|Australia}} |[[2000 ICC KnockOut Trophy|2000 Champions Trophy]] |Commenting on banter initiated by Indian cricketer [[Sachin Tendulkar]] after hitting a six, Australian bowler [[Glenn McGrath]] said, "He (Sachin) was getting stuck into me, sledging me..."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://cricket.yahoo.net/news/sachin-apos-day-confident-letting-080637261|title="It was Sachin's day, he was confident and he was letting me know," recalls Glenn McGrath|date=2018-09-07|work=Yahoo Cricket|access-date=2018-09-14}}</ref> |- |[[Michael Atherton]] and [[Kumar Sangakkara]] |March 9, 2001 |{{Flag|Sri Lanka}} vs {{Flag|England}} |[[English cricket team in Sri Lanka in 2000–01|English Cricket Team in Sri Lanka in 2001]] |England's [[Michael Atherton]] 'wagged' his finger at Sri Lanka's [[Kumar Sangakkara]] while the former was batting. Both players also claimed that the other was cheating.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/international/srilanka/3000512/Atherton-and-Sangakkara-reprimanded.html|title=Atherton and Sangakkara reprimanded|last=Berry|first=Scyld|date=2001-03-10|access-date=2018-07-12|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> |- |[[Steve Waugh]], [[Sourav Ganguly|Saurav Ganguly]] and [[Rahul Dravid]] |March 15, 2001 |{{Flag|India}} vs {{Flag|Australia}} |[[Australian cricket team in India in 2000–01|Australian Cricket Team in India in 2000-01]] |When Indian skipper [[Sourav Ganguly|Saurav Ganguly]] dropped a catch off Australian batsman [[Steve Waugh]]'s blade, the latter chirped: "You just dropped the Test, mate." Shortly after tea, Waugh lost his wicket to India's [[Harbhajan Singh]] following which Indian fieldsman [[Rahul Dravid]] jibed and sent-off Waugh asking who gave the Test match now.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tribuneindia.com/2003/20030904/sports.htm#3|title=Sledging fired up India|last=|first=|date=|website=The Tribune|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-15}}</ref> |- |[[Mark Waugh]] and [[Jimmy Ormond|James Ormond]] |August 23–27, 2001 |{{Flag|England}} vs {{Flag|Australia}} |[[2001 Ashes series|2001 Ashes]] |During the fifth test at the Oval, Australia's [[Mark Waugh]] jibed at England's [[Jimmy Ormond|James Ormond]] saying, "Look who it is. Mate, what are you doing here? There’s no way you’re good enough to play for England.” to which Ormond responded with: “Maybe not, but at least I’m the best player in my family.”<ref name=":2" /> |- |[[Sourav Ganguly|Saurav Ganguly]] and [[Russel Arnold]] |September 30, 2002 |{{Flag|Sri Lanka}} vs {{Flag|India}} |[[2002 ICC Champions Trophy|2002 Champions Trophy]] |Indian captain [[Sourav Ganguly|Saurav Ganguly]] was extremely vocal when Sri Lankan player [[Russel Arnold]] was guilty of damaging the pitch. As an altercation unfolded, umpire [[David Sheppard]] stepped in.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sportskeeda.com/slideshow/cricket-5-times-when-sourav-ganguly-bullied-opposition|title=5 times when Sourav Ganguly bullied the opposition|date=2015-11-27|access-date=2018-08-30}}</ref> |- |[[Mahela Jayawardene]], [[Sanath Jayasuriya]] and [[Herschelle Gibbs]] |November 15–19, 2002 |{{Flag|South Africa}} vs {{Flag|Sri Lanka}} |[[Sri Lankan cricket team in South Africa in 2002–03|Sri Lankan Cricket Team in South Africa in 2002-03]] |In response to 'organized' sledging by the South African cricket team in the first Test, the Sri Lankans identified five players in the South African squad to target during the second Test. As narrated by Sri Lanka's [[Mahela Jayawardene]], South Africa's [[Herschelle Gibbs]] was in tears when he came out to bat and requested Sri Lanka's [[Sanath Jayasuriya]] to stop the sledging.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.crictracker.com/herschelle-gibbs-tears-sledged-mahela-jayawardene/|title=Herschelle Gibbs was in the tears when we sledged him: Mahela Jayawardene - CricTracker|date=2017-09-25|work=CricTracker|access-date=2018-07-11|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://m.dailyhunt.in/news/india/english/cricket-epaper-cricket/herschelle+gibbs+was+in+the+tears+when+we+sledged+him+reveals+mahela+jayawardene-newsid-73954303|title=Herschelle Gibbs was in the tears when we sledged him, reveals Mahela Jayawardene - Cricket {{!}} DailyHunt|work=DailyHunt|access-date=2018-07-11|language=en}}</ref> |- |[[Kumar Sangakkara]] and [[Shaun Pollock]] |March 3, 2003 |{{Flag|South Africa}} vs {{Flag|Sri Lanka}} |[[2003 Cricket World Cup]] |In what has become a classic cricketing sledge, Sri Lankan wicketkeeper [[Kumar Sangakkara]] got under the skin of South African batsman [[Shaun Pollock]] as he came out to bat during a World Cup match between South Africa and Sri Lanka. After Sangakkara built pressure on Pollock by making him aware of the gravity of the situation, the Sri Lankan finished his sledge rant with, "Forty-two million supporters right here, depending on Shaun."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cricketnetwork.com/news/shaun-pollock-sledge-payback-kumar-sangakkara-sri-lanka-south-africa-world-cup-2003-champions-trophy/2017-06-11|title=Pollock gets payback on World Cup sledge|work=cricketnetwork.com|access-date=2018-07-11|language=en}}</ref> |- |[[Glenn McGrath]] and [[Ramnaresh Sarwan]] |May 12, 2003 |{{Flag|West Indies}} vs {{Flag|Australia}} |[[Australian cricket team in the West Indies in 2002–03|Australian Cricket Team in West Indies in 2003]] |During his sledging cameo against 21-year old West Indian batsman [[Ramnaresh Sarwan]], Australian pacer [[Glenn McGrath]] asked the former, "What does Brian Lara's dick taste like?" The West Indian responded saying, "I don't know, ask your wife."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/sport/cricket/the-nastiest-sledges-in-cricket-20131125-2y52y.html|title=The nastiest sledges in cricket|last=Decent|first=Tom|date=2013-11-25|website=The Sydney Morning Herald|language=en|access-date=2018-07-02}}</ref> This agitated McGrath whose wife was suffering from cancer at the time. McGrath then went onto say to Sarwan: "If you fucking mention my wife again, I’ll fucking rip your fucking throat out"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.indiatimes.com/sports/rewind-to-2003-glenn-mcgrath-and-ramnaresh-sarwan-have-an-altercation-which-quickly-turns-ugly-345243.html|title=Rewind To 2003 - Glenn McGrath & Ramnaresh Sarwan Have An Altercation Which Quickly Turns Ugly|work=indiatimes.com|access-date=2018-07-02|language=en}}</ref> |- |[[Nasser Hussain]], [[Muttiah Muralitharan]] and [[Kumar Sangakkara]] |December 10–14, 2003 |{{Flag|Sri Lanka}} vs {{Flag|England}} |[[English cricket team in Sri Lanka in 2003-04|English Cricket Team in Sri Lanka in 2003-04]] |English cricketer [[Nasser Hussain]] delivered several verbals to Sri Lankan cricketer [[Muttiah Muralitharan]] during a match in the latter's hometown [[Kandy]]. When it was the Englishman's turn to bat, he was greeted by Sri Lanka's [[Kumar Sangakkara]] who jibed: “What’s it like to be hated by both teams?” This was a taunt referring to Hussain being at odds with his own teammates in addition to facing resentment from the hosts.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/cricket/2016/04/14/kumar-sangakkara-the-dazzling-kind-perfectionist-sri-lanka-crick/|title=Kumar Sangakkara, the dazzling, kind perfectionist Sri Lanka cricket will miss like mad - Paul Farbrace salutes the retiring hero in Wisden|date=2016-04-14|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> |- |[[André Nel|Andre Nel]] and [[Chris Gayle]] |December 16, 2003 |{{Flag|South Africa}} vs {{Flag|West Indies}} |West Indian Cricket Team in South Africa in 2003-04 |After claiming [[Chris Gayle]]'s wicket, South African bowler [[André Nel|Andre Nel]] made obscene gestures at the West Indian cricketer and also used foul language against him. '''SOCCKET''' is a [[association football|soccer]] ball that harnesses and stores energy from play for later use as portable power source in resource-poor areas.<ref name=BX> {{cite web |url = http://bx.businessweek.com/entrepreneurship/view?url=http://www.business-opportunities.biz/2010/04/27/cool-invention-the-soccket/ |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130118140425/http://bx.businessweek.com/entrepreneurship/view?url=http://www.business-opportunities.biz/2010/04/27/cool-invention-the-soccket/ |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 18 January 2013 |work = Business Exchange |title = Cool Invention: the sOccket |publisher = Bloomberg Business |date = 27 April 2010 |first = Rich |last = Whittle }}</ref><ref> {{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/video/data/2.0/video/living/2010/06/18/nr.the.big.i.soccket.cnn.html |title=Soccer ball turns into lamp |work=CNN Live |publisher=CNN Live |date=6 July 2010 }}</ref> It is the flagship product of Uncharted Play, Incorporated.<ref name=CGIU> {{cite web |url=http://www.soccket.com/media-gallery/clinton-global-initiative/ |title=Clinton Global Initiative University 2011 }}</ref>
==History== Jessica Lin, Julia Silverman, [[Jessica O. Matthews]], Hemali Thakkar, who were at the time undergraduates at Harvard University, and Aviva Presser, who was a Harvard graduate student at the time, were the inventors listed on the initial patent. Prototypes of the ball first appeared in the media in early 2010.<ref name=NYM> {{cite journal |url=http://nymag.com/arts/all/approvalmatrix/63394/ |journal=[[New York Magazine]] |date=31 January 2010 |title=The Approval Matrix: Week of February 8, 2010 }}</ref><ref> {{cite news |url=http://green.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/01/26/using-soccer-to-supplant-kerosene-use/ |title=Using Soccer to Supplant Kerosene Use |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=26 January 2010 |first=Jim|last=Witkin }}</ref> The mass-produced version of the ball is the brainchild of Uncharted Play, Inc.--a social enterprise founded by two of the original inventors, Jessica O. Matthews and Julia C. Silverman.<ref name=CGIU/>
==Media reaction== The Soccket scored on the "Highbrow" and "Brilliant" quadrant of ''New York's'' "Approval Matrix" for the week of February 8, 2010.<ref name=NYM/>
The Soccket has been reported to have broken quickly after the first use by recipients.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pri.org/stories/2014-04-08/impoverished-kids-love-soccer-ball-powers-lamp-until-it-breaks|title=Impoverished kids love the soccer ball that powers a lamp — until it breaks |work=[[Public Radio International]]|date=Apr 8, 2014|accessdate=Apr 8, 2014}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}

{{advert|date=May 2016}} {{primary sources|date=March 2011}} [[File:Trips for Kids Recyclery Bike Shop.jpg|thumb]] '''Trips For Kids '''is a non-profit community service organization that provides beginning and intermediate-level mountain bike outings, environmental education, bicycle mechanics training and earn-a-bike programs for youth in the United States and Canada, especially those most in need. Legally based in Marin County, California, over 200,000 children have been served by 75 Trips for Kids chapters in the United States and Canada as of December 2017.<ref>http://www.tripsforkids.org</ref>
==History== Trips for Kids was founded in Marin County, California in 1988 by Marilyn Price, a social activist, environmentalist and Mountain Bike Hall of Fame inductee. Price used the mountain bike to teach at-risk, underserved youth lessons in personal responsibility, achievement and environmental awareness through the development of practical skills. Price formed the nonprofit Trips for Kids-Marin, the organization's flagship program, and began national outreach in the mid-1990's to inspire new chapters. Independent chapters began to form throughout the United States, Canada, Israel and briefly in Sierra Leone, growing to 75 chapters as of August 2017.<ref>[https://www.tripsforkids.org/our-programs/ http://www.tripsforkids.org/national/findachapter.htm]</ref>
==Programs and Chapters== In addition to the Discovery Trail Rides Program, Trips for Kids chapters may also run Adventure Ride Clubs, Earn-a-Bike Workshops, Mobile Bike Clinics, camps and other programs. Five chapters also operate Recyclery community bike thrift shops.
==National Umbrella Organization==
On August 1, 2017, a new 501c3 national umbrella organization was established to provide support for Trips for Kids chapters, build new chapters, improve program quality and promote the organization.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.tripsforkids.org}}
